description: An The Go is one of my, if not my #1, top food trucks to eat at!!! I am always looking for An The Go when i am in a food truck area! their garlic noodles are to die for (i am always craving them) and can be topped with beef, chicken, or shrimp skewers. this truck is the best place to snag a quick lunch or bite to eat!!
author: Roberta G.

description:
Got excited when I saw garlic noodles. I'm a huge noodle fan and was eager to try it out! I ordered the Garlic Noodle Combo with five spice pork, veggie stirfry and Vietnamese Crispy Rolls. Food came out quickly and the guy managing orders was very friendly.

Now for the food:
- Garlic noodles: nicely flavored, chewy, generous portion (4/5)
- Five spice pork: not very flavorful, could barely taste the five spice (2/5)
- veggie stirfry: broccoli/cauliflower nicely flavored, tofu was bland (3/5)
- Vietnamese crispy roll: TBH kind of bleh. it wasn't crispy at all, sauce could have used more punch.

Given the price ($14 for the combo + tax) I'm not sure I'd be back again.
author: Jenn C.

description:
I really should've hopped on yelp before placing an order here. Pretty disappointing to say the least....

They showed up to Off The Grid: The Lot in Oakland for lunch... great grilled meat/seafood smells flowing to the air so I got in line. By the time I got to place my order, I was told they were out of everything except the five spice pork and the lemon grass beef. I opted for the beef, paid a little over $9 and waited about 5 minutes to pick up my order. I open up my box only to find a small skewer with a little bit of beef and an average portion of garlic noodles. Don't get me wrong, the garlic noodles were decent, but the portion of beef was SMALL and chewy.

My coworker ordered the fried crab dumplings to share with everyone... crunchy on the outside, mushy and bland on the inside. I could understand paying $10 for this IF it included a couple shrimp, but man... I felt ripped off and still hungry afterwards.
author: Jason L.

description: I open the box and only find a small skewer with a little bit of beef and an average portion of noodles. The price was 9 dollars 80 cents. Very Disappointed!
author: Sing Y.

description: It's a food truck next to my work place which makes my job easier. Garlic noodles are just perfect and it goes with what side dish you order - veggies, chicken and others. I am a vegetarian and I loved the taste of noodles. A good meal for lunch
author: Siva Sruthi B.

description:
I needed some lunch today and realized it was food truck day near work! Well I've been hearing about An the Go for a while now and decided, sure why not and I just had a burrito yesterday so even though the lines at Tacos de los Altos was significantly longer, I stuck to my guns. The verdict? I should've had anything else but this, but hey now I know better. The noodles were over cooked, but had a nice little garlic tingle to them. The Five Spice Pork not dry, flavorful, but not remarkable. 

L O C A T I O N
An the Go is a food truck so you'll have to check out their schedule. I was able to catch them in San Ramon Bishop Ranch.

P A R K I N G
Again depending on where you catch the truck. At Bishop Ranch there's plenty of parking as it's a business park. I didn't have to drive anywhere so convenient for me.

M E N U
They basically serve garlic noodles with skewers. They have two different combos:

~ Garlic noodles combo - $ 14 + tax ~
Choose two meats/veggie
- Lemongrass chicken
- Yuzu shrimp
- Vegetable stirfry
- Five spice pork
- Lemongrass beef
Choose one side
- Vietnamese crispy roll with dipping sauce
- Dungeonous crab puff with mustard sauce

~ Original combo - $9 + tax ~
Choose one meat/veggie (same as above)

Then they have sides same as the above but the crispy roll is $6 for 2 rolls, puffs are $6 as well. They do have a few drinks, Fiji water, diet coke...and another drink which I didn't capture.

I ordered the original with five-spice pork as this was their best seller in terms of meat. The meat itself wasn't too shabby. Nice grilled taste, pork was not dry. The bed of garlic noodles on the other hand were the disappointment. They were overcooked and mushy. The garlic taste was prominent and it was oily but that was to be expected. If you don't want to have dragon breath for the rest of the day, you shouldn't have this otherwise, hey...embrace the garlic! I kind of wish they could do a side of veggies or something that can lighten up the dish. Even some cilantro would've probably helped the meal Heck even put the noodles on a romaine lettuce. There's just missing a crunchy textural element.

S E R V I C E
Since it's grilled fresh, it does take time. The lines are fairly long during noon so get there early. It took about half an hour to get through the line and get the food. The person at the window was at least cheery even though it was blistery hot. So that's a plus.

O V E R A L L
Unless you really love noodles or just want to try it out, then sure try An the Go. Otherwise, the only thing really going for it is the punny name. I will not be back.
author: Carolen M.

description:
For lunch at the BR1 food truck mafia, I got some noodles to go from An the Go.  Its a food truck that specializes in garlic noodles with protein on the side.  The owners are the same folks from Thanh Long and Crustacean - both upscale Vietnamese restaurants in SF that specialize in roasted crab.  I haven't tried their garlic noodles in a long time, so seeing the truck brought back some fond memories of my carefree grad student days at Berkeley.

I ordered the garlic noodles with a side of lemongrass chicken.  Chicken was very flavorful and juicy.  It had an odd texture at first and I thought it was ground chicken at first.  In the end, I liked the chicken.  Noodles were chewy, garlicky, and surprisingly very filling!  I was almost tempted to get another item from Koja Kitchen, but thankfully I did not.
author: Daniel C.

description: If I could give this place a zero I would. They should contemplate naming their garlic noodles to just "Plain old noodles"... I've tried many garlic noodles spots around the bay and this is the WORST I've been to! I would advice the owners/chef to go back to the drawing board because charging people top dollar for amateur food is wrong.
author: Destiny R.

description:
Great Vietnamese food.  Garlic noodles  so authentic and with pork.  
The Vietnamese coffee is a bit too sweet
Great variety of meats but this is so good. Thank god they come to SF city hall civic center on Fridays.
author: David C.

description: Four small shrimps on a bed of over cooked noodles for $9.80. Not worth the price nor the calories.
author: S G.

description:
An the No is more like it.

As a lot of other reviewers mentioned, An the Go food truck's garlic noodles to protein ratio is off. There's too many noodles and not enough protein. The garlic noodles were too mushy and didn't have a strong garlicky aroma. The lemongrass beef skewer was a bit dry, but decent, and it had very thinly sliced meat. The yuzu shrimp skewer, which had decent-sized shrimp, smelled a little off (strongly fishy) and wasn't very flavorful either.

If An the Go is a representation of Thanh Long's quality, then I'd avoid Thanh Long at all costs.
author: Priscilla W.

description:
Very nice food truck friendly customer service great menu. Very diverse selection of chicken, beef, shrimp and pork skewers over garlic noodles. 
He prawns and we're cooked perfectly and the garlic noodles were savory and sweet I would definitely order there again everything was fresh and made to order.
author: Michelle H.

description: Loved the beef and garlic noodles. I actually asked for the peanut mustard sauce on the side and mixed it in. It was really yummy. I feel bad for everyone around me that can smell my garlic breath.
author: Brooke S.

description:
I don't think I'll be coming here again. I ordered garlic noodles with pork on top, and the amount of pork I was given was laughable. I'd say I was able to finish all the meat that came in my dish in maybe four bites. Additionally, the garlic noodles themselves, while plentiful, were not the tastiest dish I've ever experienced. The noodles themselves were standard affair and comparable to spaghetti, and the garlic sauce was on the dry side, and not as flavorful as I would have expected. I was also surprised that it wasn't that filling, even though the portion of noodles looked substantial.

In conclusion, I am not sure An The Go has hit the mark with their garlic noodles, the toppings that come with them, or the price they charge. Until some changes are made or I don't have any other choice, I doubt I'll be trying the same dish again.
author: John B.

description:
Yummy yum yum is all I can say! I had some An The Go for my first time at the On The Grid in Belmont on a Monday evening and I was so happy to see this truck!

Garlic Noodles was what I was feenin for and I know they had some on this truck. I seen the menu and was very happy to see that they had a menu combo. So I went all in!

I ordered the Garlic Noodles with Lemongrass Beef and the shrimp! The customer service I received was great and no complaints at all!

I ordered my food and received it in less than 5 minutes. Once I got to a location where I could devour my food in peace I was in Heaven!

How was the food, you are asking? Well:
Garlic Noodles: it was very good and tasteful! I would definitely order them again.
Lemongrass Beef: I wasn't so pleased about, I felt that it was dry and been sitting out for a while. I wouldn't order this again.
Shrimp: Was delicious but nothing to brag about
Vietnamese Roll: Was very good, they gave me a little sauce with it which was like a teaser. I would definitely ask for my dipping sauce next time.

Overall, I truly enjoyed the garlic noodles and think that next time I would just stick with getting that and ONLY that! For the price of my dinner I don't think it was worth it but it was all about the Garlic Noodles!
author: Porsche C.

description: This is my definition of good truck food. Garlic noodles were amazing as was the skewered many-spice chicken. I had to eat here a couple days in a row I liked it so much.
author: Benjamin A.

description:
Food was decent to fairly good (3-4 stars, depending on what you get); service was friendly but suuuuuper slow, so going with 3 stars overall.

I got the garlic noodle combo with steak, shrimp, and a crispy roll, and I also ordered a side of crab puffs.

The crispy roll was the best item by far; I'd definitely get that again. Really crispy and flavorful.

Second runner up was the steak, which was good. Everything else was fine, but not memorable. The portion of noodles is quite generous, which I appreciated, but their texture got weird once they cooled off a bit; it quickly felt and tasted like I was eating 2-day old leftovers, which I have nothing wrong with, except that they weren't even an hour old yet... Oh well.

I'd definitely put this in the "comfort food" category. So if that's what you're in the mood for, and you don't mind a wait, then you'll be satisfied!
author: Liz F.

description:
The concept of garlic noodles with a skewer of choice of meat, is fabulous, but their follow through on quality, needs improvement!  

The portion of garlic noodles, were generous, but it lacked presentation.  I ordered up their Yuzu Shrimp as the skewer and that lacked umph.  I felt like I was eventually eating endless amounts of garlic noodles that didn't quite erk me to snazzy taste.  The combo was 9 bucks (could have spent that on smething noteworthy, but decided to give this truck a try).  

They conveniently accept credit cards.

Next truck!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I discovered An the Go at Sunday's Food Truck fiesta @ Marin Mart. I was really hungry and only had 10 bucks in my wallet. Most of the other food trucks offered meals in the over $10 price range (when did food trucks start getting so damn expensive?!).

Fortunately, An the Go had a garlic noodle dish that comes with a lemongrass chicken skewer for just 9 bucks. It totally hit the spot. The chicken breast was freshly cooked and served on top of a generous portion of garlic noodles with parmesan cheese. These garlic noodles are certainly worth a return visit. And yes, folks... they are VERY garlic-y (like a 9 on a scale of 1-10)! So I wouldn't recommend eating them if you've got a hot date later that day).

All in all, An the Go was a delightful Sunday afternoon discovery. I'll be back!
author: Kevin B.

description:
Had their regular combo today in downtown SF for $9.80 including tax. I was not pleased and left me unsatisfied.

The combo basically came with 1 skewer/3 pieces of lemongrass beef and garlic noodle in the box. The quality/texture of the beef was good, but it lacked the lemongrass taste. All I got out from the beef was salt. The garlic noodle was a little bit over cooked but it does have the usual Thanh Long scent and taste.
author: Aaron K.

description: If I could give zero stars I would.  15$ dollars for some over cooked gummy noodles and rear lightly cooked lemon grass beef that is missing the lemongrass flavor or any flavor.  I am so disappointed.  I will never buy from this truck again that is on the corner of 11th and Broadway RIGHT NOW!!!! Stay away you will be mad. I too mad to wait for the pic to upload.  In the garbage it goes.
author: Ishtar P.

description:
Went to OtG El Cerrito and came across An The Go (nice play on words).

As soon as I saw 'Garlic Noodles', I wanted to try it. We ordered Garlic Noodles + Salt & Pepper Soft Shell Crab and Garlic Noodles + Yuzu Shrimp and Lemongrass beef and Crab puffs. When it comes to the taste, the garlic noodles were good, no complaints there. With the soft shell crab, it was kind of soggy and a little too salty. The shrimp was small and the beef was a little dry, but has potential to be good. 

Portion wise, it is small for what you're paying. Maybe it was just my order that was a little smaller after looking at some of the other pictures on Yelp. I understand food trucks may cost a little more in comparison to a restaurant, but that was definitely not worth $14.
author: Kyle B.

description: Got chicken and shrimp noodles.. wish there were more flavors in this dish. Chicken was pretty fatty. Doesn't seem too healthy, noodles were good, shrimp were without tails which was a plus. Best part of the meal was crab rangoons with that sweet sweet honey mustard sauce.. two bad it only came with two rangoons. Would be better with more vegetables to add some healthy variety to the meal. And more crab rangoons.
author: Jakob Eats Alone ..

description: So disappointed - Ordered the garlic noodles with the flank steak. The steak was 4 slices of gristle - just tossed it. The entire concept of this truck needs a re-think - heaping mound of dry mediocre tasting garlic noodles with a  single skewer of meat (shrimp, chicken or steak). Couldn't you incorporate some vegetable in this combo? All up it was gross and a rip-off. Seems like the owners of this truck have lost interest - because this was just sad. #Yuck
author: Todd S.

description:
It always confuses why food trucks charge more for less.  I mean you don't have a fixed monthly rent to pay, and you open only at peak hours so your staffing costs are also minimized.  An The Go isn't the exception, but the rule.  Back in the day, food trucks were called roach mobiles, but that was when they were unsanitary and roach infested.  Yelp shows that An The Go got a health score of 94/100 so I guess roaches are pretty scared of this place.

Well I needed a quick bite and my friend suggested we try some food trucks that park at a local hotel next to where we work.  Having an urge to eat some Chinese food An The Go looked like a good fit.  I order the 14+tax combo which included a half box of garlic noodles, a short stick of lemon grass beef, and a short stick of 5 flavored pork.  The total was $15.25 and I tipped 10% which made my meal $16.77.  The lemom grass beef and 5 flavored pork were both pretty good.  But it was like 4 pcs each on a 5 inch skewer.  Common An The Go, I get more meat then that on a hamburger at Micky Ds. 

Then came the noodles....they were definitely over cooked and drenched with oil.  It might be the garlic sauce that they use, but the noodles ended up having a soggy texture and almost soaked through the bottom of the box when I finished.  Also for $16, you'd think they would use a full size square box vs a half size take out box.  I usually see this size box for hot dogs or for left overs.

At least they keep the truck clean and I didn't get the runs afterwards so that got them 2 stars.  But common An The Go, if your gonna charge $16, at least use a full size take out box.
author: Hankle O.

description:
Brought to you from the An Family of the popular Thanh Long restaurant is An the Go.  An the Go is a their food truck which serves their oh so good garlic noodles.  A year after they opened, I finally tried it at Off the Grid.  One word: soggy.

FOOD:
I decided to go with the special for the day: softshell over garlic noodles ($14).  It's expensive for the amount of food, but it's typical food truck prices (combos are $9).  The softhshell crab was nicely done with a crispy exterior.  It was deep fried and coated with salt and pepper.  The garlic noodles on the other hand was soggy and missing the heavy garlic taste.  

Bottom line:  if you want good garlic noodles, head into their restaurant instead.  

LOCATION:
Expect them at most Off the Grid gatherings throughout the week.  However for their exact location, check their Facebook or Twitter pages.
author: Nicole S.

description:
5/11/15: First time this truck showed up at work.  I probably don't have much to add beyond what the ~300 other reviewers said before me, you know, way too expensive, sides (and meat) are tiny, noodles are good.  But well, here it is from me:

1. "$14 Garlic Noodle Combo" $14: So, here the price is part of the item name, if that foretells anything.  There is a $9 combo.  So, you either go with rich people price or if you aren't feeling like shelling that kind of money for a plate of noodles, you got an option of nearly 1/2 off the price for maybe 1/5th less food..... k...so how is it 40% less for just a bit less food?  Cause the skewers were small and the side of Dungeness Crab Puffs was absolutely miniscule.  So if you get one less skewer and no side, it's not really that much less food, and not a huge loss.

1a. Garlic Noodles: Yeah, they're good.  But if you put a little bit of effort into it, I'm sure you can make the same thing at home without much trouble.  Heck, I have myself.  Just get fresh noodles from Ranch 99 of your choice, and cook with butter and lots of minced garlic.  That's just about it.  Looks like they added some parmesan or something for texture--you can do the same if you want.  When I went to Crustacean in Beverly Hills many years ago, I feel like it might have been better then (I guess this truck is owned by the same people?)  The noodles this time were a tad overcooked, and could use a little more firmness.  They also opened AnQi in Costa Mesa many years ago just specializing in those noodles.  I've been to South Coast Plaza where it's located many times, but never had the desire to pay $20 or whatever crazy price they were asking for a plate of simple noodles.  6/10.

1b. Five-Spice Pork [skewer]: You get about 3 or so decent bite-sized pieces.  Has a good amount of flavor, but it tastes a bit off to me.  The meat is a bit dry and overcooked, but not too badly.  Nothing special here.  5/10.

1c. Lemongrass Beef [skewer]: Meat was good quality (skirt steak maybe?) and cooked mediumish, which I was pleased to find.  Spices tasted good too.  Good stuff.  Also about 3 pieces.  Pretty good.  7/10.

1d. Dungeness Crab Puffs: Utter sht.  Come on.  Almost false advertising.  "Puffs"?  I was expecting like pastries stuffed with crab.  Nope.  These are standard small wontons stuffed with some crab meat.  They were even over-fried!--very close to simply burnt!!!  I could not believe that.  The stuffing was on the dry side.  Yes, it's crab, but it's not good crab.  Not juicy.  No flavor.  2 pieces.  Yeah, this is bad stuff.  I got this as part of the combo, but PLEASE do not pay $6 for it standalone!!!  2/10.

If you really want to try their good stuff, go to Crustacean--I really do like their crab.  Might have been some of the best I've ever had (again, Beverly Hills location--not sure how that compares to up here.)  If you do go, my tip is just get the crab--everything else sucked as I remember, including even lobster!  And like I said, I walked by AnQi many times and said hell no.

Anyway, ignoring the crab "puffs" everything else was decent tasting, but at ripoff-level prices.

Still keeping it at 3/5 (instead of 2/5) stars despite the pricing cause it tasted good enough (again, ignoring those crab things), and the steak probably wasn't cheap, and given they give a lot of noodles I am rather full, so I'd probably eat this again if I didn't have another lunch choice, and yeah this is a mega run-on sentence.

#truck #noodles
author: Dean C.

description:
Had their famous noodles several months ago at the Hiller Aviation. Museum with my coworkers and I'll tell you exactly what I told then.

Go...go..go to another food truck.

These noodles taste like they were prepared in the following manner: cook noodles, then dump garlic powder all over, and mix.

Super salty. Didn't taste like fresh garlic at all.

 I took two bites and threw it away.
author: Jack R.

description: Three stars for the garlic noodles. The noodles are cooked well. I ordered the lemon grass skewers and so it said these are supposed to be chicken thigh meat. However, as soon as I bit into it, it tasted like it was chicken breast and not thigh. For chicken thigh meat, this tasted really, really dry. Pretty much over cooked. All in all, I would rate higher in stars if it wasn't for that one factor. Cost is $9.80 so decent price for lunch compared to if you were to go to Thanh long for garlic noodles.
author: Sheena C.

description:
Alright so I tried this place again and got the Lemongrass Chicken skewer with the noodles. Again, not the most flavorful, but the chicken was really tender and had a nice little punch of citrus flavor. The noodles are definitely oily so if you're not into that, then this place probably isn't for you. However, if you're okay with that and you really love garlic noodles, then this place is perfect for you. $9 for a HUGE portion of noodles that will last you two meals is a great deal in my book!

They seem to have added a new combo option where you get the noodles, 2 skewers, and one of their side dishes for $14. Pricey yes, but I'm sure the portion is worth it.
author: Karen T.

description: So disappointed when I opened the box. 4 small shrimps laid on the noodles, sadly. The protion of protein and carbs are so off. Get it only if you like to eat plain noodles， but even so , the taste of noodles doesn't worth $10。
author: Luyan D.

description:
Love love love An the Go for their GARLIC NOODLES!

I believe the very first time we tried the food truck is back when SactoMoFo had their very first Humongus food truck event at Fremont Park in Sacramento. The long lines were horrendous that we were waiting for an hour literally for food!  I did order their famous garlic noodles with several meat skewer options like pork and shrimp. My only gripe is I wish they would have a little more meat and/or veggie with the entree.
The skewers were extra in cost unless they have a combined special with both.
I have also had their coconut shrimp which is deep fried BTW and quite tasty.

I have also hit An the Go at a couple of other major SactoMoFo events but mainly at the Off the Grid event in San Francisco on Fridays at Fort Mason. If you haven't ever been to that event, you are missing out! They usually have 30 plus food trucks/tents
and I've noticed they have music lately.  I think bc it's winter season it's not up until maybe March or April?  Just check Off the Grid site.

Yes, I highly recommend this food truck and if I come across them like I have in the past like Off the Grid in Alameda, SF Civic Center or in Treasure Island, I will be ordering an entree of those TDF garlic noodles!  You can bet on that! God, I could go for that right this minute! The weekend is coming up...hmmmm.  LOL.
author: Karen K.

description: I have been to this food truck multiple times and I'm obsessed. Mt favorite dish is the garlic noodles + shrimp skewers. The garlic noodles taste better when you add some type of protein to it so other people in reviews have expressed $2.50 being a bit pricey for the skewers it definitely makes the mea" 2x better.
author: Christina G.

description: Are you a fan of garlic noodles or cacio pepe (with less black pepper)? Then this may be up your alleyi certainly think these garlic noodles are delicious, but I'm not sure if I'm getting a good value. The heaping portion of garlic noodles sure is generous, but in the end, it's noodle and it's not handmade noodle. I liked the yuzu shrimp the most, but the lemongrass beef and five spice pork were not bad either. Wonderful Asian grill flavors. I also tried the crab puff and it was okay. Service is great. All in all, the noodles are stellar and I wish it were a little cheaper. Would probably go great as the side to a crab dinner (once, I took these noodles to go and added some more parm and red chili flakes, and thought tasted pretty superb) , but can't really eat such a large ratio of noodle to protein/veggie.
author: Jennifer W.

description: An The Go is a great food truck. They have presence inn Marin on Sundays and a few places in the city. I was so impressed with the quality of the my noodles. They were fresh and had great chewyosity. The Garlic is king on these and the parm cheese make it unique. I loved it. I selected the Chinese 5 Spice Pork Skewer on top. Nice marriage of flaover. Many other toppings to choose from including veggie. So good. Drooling. Next time I will have a beer with it. Great portion size.
author: Thomas B.

description: We are big fans of the garlic noodles from here. We usually get extra to-go! Veggies and shrimp are always cooked perfectly and compliment the noodles well making it a well rounded delicious lunch! We always go to Off the Grid when we know An the Go is going to be there!!!
author: Sierra M.

description:
I see this truck parked in my hood by the Crustacean all the time. I guess they just park there because the truck is never open in that hood. 
I finally went today when they were parked in the FiDi (Soma actually). It was garlicky goodness.
I used to go to the Crustacean occasionally and thought it was awesome. Haven't been in years. An the Go is a nice reunion. The noodles are BOMB and the meat was actually excelllent. I got the pork and chicken. Super tasty. The little fried crab dumpling things with the mustard sauce were fantastic.
I was talking too much during lunch outside to my coworker so my noodles got cold too fast (kind of windy and chilly outside) which was a bummer because slurping these babies down while they are piping hot is about as good as it gets. Will definitely repeat again.
author: Matt H.

description: The cigarette smoking hoody driving the An the go food truck thinks it's totally okay to partially block the driveway to the building I live in, despite being asked to move by multiple people driving into the building. If this is their attitude to people, then I suspect their food sucks. Anyway, cops are on the way so there goes their profits for today.
author: Ian F.

description: I ordered the garlic noodles with what was supposed to be lemongrass chicken. I opted for the combo, 2 skewers of chicken and an egg roll. The egg roll was absolutely fantastic. Crispy, with flavorful filling. The noodles and chicken on the other hand were not good at all. The noodles were a mushy greasy combo and the chicken had some sort of strange aftertaste. It was moist, but it was strange. The worse part definitely was the price. Including tax it was over 15 dollars. Complete rip off for what you receive
author: Germany K.

description:
Is there anything better than free food? Well, yes, freedom in general is pretty bitchen. But free food, IMPO, is a close second.

Today 10.22, Citibank card holders got to grab a voucher in 3 different branches and indulge in 3 different tasty food truck foods! I thanked my lucky stars that I transferred my balance to a Citibank credit card (with 0% interest for 15 months, mind you) and headed out with my co-worker. Initially I just wanted my favorite Senior Sisig on California, but we hit up Post St first and An the Go was waiting outside. 

Dudes, I love garlic. And I love pasta, and noodles, but mainly in pho and mainly flat large noodles. Chow Mein is lost on me, I think of it as filler, and normally pass. But today, it being free and all, and the only option, save for meat / veggies, I went with the Garlic Noodles and Pork Skewer.

Holy tastebuds, Batman! Buttery, garlicky, thick noodles, hot and fresh! Oh my, I think i have found a new indulgent craving. I saved half for my lunch tomorrow, and I actually just went and took a nibble (because I have no self control and the thought of those bad boys chilling in the fridge made me wonder how they taste cold. And they taste amazing.) Not sure why people be hatin' on ATG, I had a great time, and I don't think my opinion is biased because it just happened to be free.
author: Crystal C.

description:
I love garlic noodles, and while it hurts to write this review because the folks in the food truck are super nice, the price is just not equivalent to what you get in your meal.

Don't get me wrong. It's definitely a hefty box. However, the ratio of non-noodles to noodles is disappointing. I only had a couple of pieces of meat, some veggies, and basically the rest was garlic noodles. Yeah, garlic noodles are great, I get it, but holy moly, there is a time when one has to stop and think, "My God. This is...a LOT of garlic noodles."

The noodles themselves were tasty, but again, it's the price point that's off-putting. There are other places where you can get the same weight of food but with a better distribution of non-noodles. I'd rather go to a different truck and feel less full in exchange for more flavor and variety in my box.
author: Robbin A.

description: I recently tried this truck for lunch at the SFO Airport Food Truck Stop. Everything on the menu looked great from combos to just garlic noodles and lemongrass chicken plate. I ordered the 1skewer of Lemon grass chicken which had lots of flavor placed on top of their famous garlic noodles. The huge portion of noodles just needed something else added to it like veggies or another chicken skewer , but I loved it anyways !!! will try this truck again and the staff great!
author: Michelle M.

description:
Thursdays is Food Truck night at Chameleon Café. And owner Melody acquired another "Off the Grid" food truck to park in front of her café. Food Truck: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wxitWND4sjRCKBpaNq32Kw?select=wEyc0rOCA7Op3CglNqoFwg#CMW1gg0-w5A1KidzcmMoYg

Last night, she got a noodle truck from "An the go". The noodle truck is best known for their Vietnamese and Asian infused garlic flavored pasta. 

And that is what I ordered with a grilled Lemongrass Chicken on a skewer as a combo for $9.00. The pasta had a huge garlic flavor. But the bonehead pasta was nothing too spectacular. The single Chicken piece is breast meat seasoned in a variety of Asian spices. Maybe too much; the chicken was a tad too salty. 

My meal: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wxitWND4sjRCKBpaNq32Kw?select=wEyc0rOCA7Op3CglNqoFwg#jayTDbX08EBlfwzaXHCGaQ 

As I was afflicting with my pasta dish, I was sipping on a $4.00 bottle of Racer-5 IPA brew. Unfortunately the Healdsburg beer was the best part of my meal. 

I continue to support Melody, her café, and try to attend as much of her Thursday food truck events whenever I can. But I was not impressed with this noodle truck though.
author: Matt G.

description:
I recently tried this food truck at the San Mateo Night market and I must admit it wasn't one of the trucks top of my list to try but I didn't have to go chasing it around the Peninsula in order to try it.

I ordered the Garlic Noodles with Lemongrass Chicken ($9 http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wxitWND4sjRCKBpaNq32Kw?select=wEyc0rOCA7Op3CglNqoFwg#6Li2FMGAF3qQUnJU0MS7vw) which smelt amazing! Upon eating I was somewhat disapointed, maybe it's because us Brits have a different idea to what Noodles are as these Noodles had the texture and flavor more like Spaghetti to me. They were tasty though, I do enjoy a Garlic fest from time to time and if it's smoothered on some complex carbs even better!

The portion size is very decent. At least the Noodles are anyway and way too much for one person, the Chicken skewer was actually quite small and I wish they would make the Noodle portion smaller and give a bit more meat. Hey.. I like me some Protein with my Carbs please. 
If you come on a food truck outing with friends I would suggest splitting a portion of Noodles and either getting additional skewers or just getting your Protein elsewhere, maybe then you wouldn't feel quite so jipped.
author: Emmalouise B.

description:
In a city full of really great food options, it's pretty impressive that all these expensive food trucks survive when there are a bunch of cheaper and tastier restaurants around. It's already an uphill battle when I have to pay $9 for a little skewer over a bed of noodles. 

My yakitori-esque beef skewer exemplified the limitations of food truck cooking. There's a good reason why skewers are normally grilled over an open flame rather than cooked on a griddle in a food truck. A griddle is fine for pancakes and eggs, but with the unevenness of skewers, a lot of the meat can't directly touch the metal top, and you end up getting chunks of gray meat instead of a nice dark sear all around. Without the even charring and caramelization you'd get from a real grill, the skewer was missing a lot of flavor. 

The noodles were pretty bland too. They weren't very buttery or garlicky. I mostly just tasted the doughy flavor of the noodles. The weird part is that even though they weren't very flavorful, the noodles were still greasy and left me with garlic breath for the rest of the day. How does that work?
author: Nei N.

description:
Given that their restaurants Thanh Long and Crustacean are $$$, An the Go is definitely a cheaper alternative. Their small and easy menu also embodies what food trucks are supposed to be. 

Garlic Noodles ($7.50)
Having gone to Thanh Long not too long before trying An the Go, I was able to compare the two garlic noodles. Not only was the noodle cheaper at the truck, I found it to be more flavorful and fragrant than the one I had at the restaurant. Also, the portion of noodles was huge here!

Lemongrass Beef Skewer ($2.50)
The skewer was cooked perfectly. It added great flavors to the garlic noodles. The only downside was the small size of the skewer. One was not enough for the portion of garlic noodles.

Tip: Order 2-3 skewers and split an order of garlic noodles with a friend.
author: Marti L.

description: I attended Off The Grid in Pleasanton and saw this food truck and I was so excited since I love Thanh Long and love the garlic noodles. I ordered just a side of the garlic noodles and the lemongrass chicken w/garlic noodles. The food was very good but we all got extremely sick from the food and I am very disappointed. Who knew that this would make us sick but I will no longer be coming to this food truck and that's just a crying shame.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
For $9+tax (original combo), I got exactly 4 shrimps, plain garlic noodles and nothing else - it even looks sad when you open the box. 
I also feel quite bad physically after eating it, and now am sipping green tea to recover. 
You can definitely find something tastier and healthier for the same price.
author: Thomas G.

description: Sorry to give this place 2 stars but c'mon, NINE DOLLARS for .25 worth of noodles and four tiny shrimp? The noodles were good -- and such a big portion that I was able to make a bangin' salad out of the leftovers the next day -- but I was sort of surprised to see such a tiny portion of meat.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Wifey was craving something noodley, so she got in line for these so-called famous noodles...She came back with a  Grilled Shrimp Skewer with Garlic Noodles. What a total disappointment it was.

The shrimp weren't plump and juicy, but kinda dry and on its way to tough, and the noodles? Waaay past al dente, and instead of that nice chewiness, it was mush.

Even the Wax Moth Larvae Taco we previously had was better!...NEXT!........ALOHA!!!

YELP 365 CHALLENGE-(266/365) "An The NO-Go"
author: Nelson Q.

description:
Never heard of this truck until yesterday. Since they were serving at my work, I decided to give it a try. I've always had this thing for trying garlic noodles so of course I was going to try it.

The minute my coworker and I stepped outside of our building, we instantaneously smelled the aroma of the garlic noodles. I decided to try the lemongrass chicken with the noodles since it was a hit or miss for these yelpers. 

When I opened up the box, I must say I got a mix of curiousness and disappointment. One measly, tiny piece of chicken on a stick. You call that garlic noodles with chicken? That looks more of a teaser than meat for the dish. After taking a bite of the noodle, I must admit it was quite delicious. It's not too garlicky, which is something I am usually wary about. The tiny piece of chicken was alright. It had the seasoning but tasted like it was sitting on the grill for a bit too long. As we reached towards the end of the dish, we noticed how GREASY the bottom of our box was. Oh boy, one of those heavy food...

Overall, this truck is alright...food had good flavor but it was way too greasy for my liking. Price is a bit stiff..but it is a food truck. Had I known how greasy it was, I probably would've gone to a different food truck. I probably won't be back for this.
author: Deekay V.

description:
I opened yelp right after I opened my lunch box to make sure it wasn't just bad luck. A box full of noodles and exactly four pieces of shrimp. And that $9+

And that point the taste didn't matter, though it tasted good.
author: Suman C.

description:
It took a while, but I finally took the plunge and caved into trying An The Go's Garlic Noodles.  I've had them before at Thanh Long, but I was very curious if they were just as good from the truck.  Especially since the lines for it a usually pretty long from the food truck meetups I've been to.

I managed to catch them at the last Moveable Feast in San Mateo.  And I couldn't resist trying it since the line wasn't too long.  I ordered the Garlic Noodles with one Shrimp Skewer (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=F_5_UNX-wrAFCXuAkBZRDw&select=JV_lmyhmstAVhxSFj7hw5A).  The Noodles were tasty and they actually give you a good amount for $7.  But for some reason they weren't the same as having them at their restaurant.  And I wouldn't suggest ordering a skewer with your noodles unless you want to get ripped off.  I had mine with Shrimp and got 3 measly shrimp for $3.  $1 a shrimp.  I don't know about it that pricing.

I would suggest picking up the noodles here and get your protein from another truck if you happen to be at a truck event.  The noodles went well with the Mandarin Chicken Taco from Streez Eatz.

Well I guess if I have a super craving for their Garlic Noodles then I would go back.  They are slightly better than Little Green Cyclo's Garlic Noodles, but at least LGC's Noodles come with a nice amount of meat on them for a $8.  A better deal in my opinion.
author: Rodney H.

description:
I should've read some reviews before trying this truck.

Found An The Go at Off the Grind in Palo Alto. Feeling hungry, I got their $14 garlic noodle combo with 5 spice pork, yuzu shrimp and crab puffs.

Like others have said, the crab puffs were extremely disappointing, tiny, and just not tasty. Opening the container that held the noodles was another disappointment; it's like looking into a desert. The noodles were plain looking, with no dressing besides some garlic bits. The desert came with a slab of pork and 3 pieces of shrimp, each being just OK. The noodles were too garlicy and lacked any other flavor. 

I don't give out 1 stars often, but in my opinion because of the price, portions, and tastes, An The Go deserves it.
author: Phillip Y.

description:
This is more of a 3 1/2 star which makes me wish that Yelp has 1/2 star options but since the staff was friendly and I would get food from them again, I'll bump them up to 4.  

I've always been a big fan of the garlic noodles at Crustacean and Thanh Long so I have been hoping to see them pop up at an East Bay OTG.  Years later, I finally saw that they were at the Alameda one this past Sat so we rushed over and got there 30 min before they closed. 

Food:  I didn't see the option for garlic noodles only so had to get the $9 "meal" and since I was buying for the fam, ended up with a $27 dent in my wallet for 1 chicken w/lemongrass, 1 beef w/lemongrass, and 1 five spice pork.  The beef that I had was very tasty and would definitely get it again.  The other two skewers also seemed to go over well with the recipients of those meals taste wise.  The garlic noodles was loaded with garlic flavor that I was still tasting it in my mouth hours later.  Unfortunately maybe because it's being kept warm vs. made to order due to time constraints, the noodles can be mushy so not quite the same texture as the ones directly from the restaurant. 

Cost:  As many others complained, the skewers are quite small and although I would not want them to decrease the amount of noodles just to match the skewer portion, $9 is a bit high for noodles and a tiny bit of meat.  You do have an option of adding extra skewers for $2.50 each but maybe having 2 skewers + noodles for $10 might be a better deal and leave people feeling more satisfied.
author: Joyce Z.

description:
Ordered the garlic noodle w/ Lemongrass chicken skewer and a side of Yuzu shrimp skewer.

It's $9 for garlic noodle and one skewer. You can pick from Lemongrass chicken, yuzu shrimp, five-spice pork, vegetable stir-fry or lemongrass beef.
$14 gives you garlic noodle, pick two skewers, and either the Vietnamese-crispy roll w/ dipping sauce or the Dungeness  crab prude w/ peanut-mustard sauce.
If you prefer to add extra skewers, it's $2.50.

Definitely check it out if you're a fan of garlic noodles.
author: Henry C.

description:
3.5 Stars

I'm a big fan of the An family of restaurants, having taken students to interview dinners at Thanh Long many times.  Crustacean is too touristy and priced accordingly, but the food is still excellent.  

Was hoping in the food truck format to get a better value ratio, but the garlic noodles at $7.50 are still a bit pricey for just noodles without any meat of any sort.  You can add skewers for $2.50 extra, but the price adds up quickly.

The garlic noodles were prepared well, but our lemongrass chicken skewer (dark meat) was a bit burned.  Ok flavor but didn't really appreciate the lemongrass.

If you have a craving for garlic noodles, definitely come here, but know it's not the best bang for the buck.

An The Go accepts credit cards, but not American Express.
author: Randy F.

description: Crustaceans on wheels! Not the entire menu, but still great food, great prices, great staff! I'm about to demolish these garlic noodles!!!!
author: Corey B.

description: Noodles themselves are great. The frozen and squishy vegetables ruined the dish. Unfortunately mine were still frozen....
author: Cara M.

description:
Garlic Noodles!

That's really all that they're known for. I got to try this food truck at the SF Treasure Island Flea Market. I'm a really big fan of noodles so I really wanted to try it, and judging from the line, I thought this place was worth a try.

Garlic Noodles with Yuzu Shrimp: $9. They give you an option of what meat you want with it, like lemongrass beef/chicken or shrimp. The meat comes in the form of a skewer, and there wasn't much to it. I did like the shrimp though! It was marinated in Yuzu juice which is a citrus fruit juice, and it tasted delicious. The shrimp was really zesty and it went really well with the garlic noodles. The garlic noodles did taste good for like the first couple of bites, they had a really nice creamy garlic sauce but, after that it was way too oily to eat. 

In comparison to other food trucks I've had, i think there are better ones for the same price.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
If "An The Go" is a mobile advertisement for the An Family's Award-Winning Restaurants: Thanh Long and Crustacean then I would say, NEXT!
 
Yesterday, 4.28.11, my friend and I came to Off The Grid - Upper Haight and I had no anticipation of trying ATG since they weren't on OTG's Facebook Event List. However, even though we were thoroughly stuffed from Chairman Bao and 3-Sum Eats, I couldn't give up the opportunity to try their "famous" garlic noodles. Unlike other trucks, there was no line at ATG's truck. 

MENU:
*An's Famous Garlic Noodles - $7.50
*Skewers: Lemongrass Beef or Chicken, Five-Spice Pork - $2.50
*Crispy Roll - $2
*Crab Puff - $4
*Viet Ice Coffee - $3

I placed my order with the nice gentleman and my garlic noodles were ready in about 3 minutes. CC's accepted. 

What A Solid, Mouth-Watering Plate Of Garlic Noodles Should Be...
You should be able to smell the aroma of garlic permeating in the air seconds before the heaping plate of garlic noodles is brought to you. As you take the first bite, the fragrant smell of garlic should hit you in the face followed by your taste buds. The taste should be garlicky and buttery rich but not overwhelming to the point where it leaves your mouth with a stringent garlic taste. The noodles should be al-dente with a soft, chewy consistency. 

AN'S FAMOUS GARLIC NOODLES - DISAPPOINTING!
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wxitWND4sjRCKBpaNq32Kw?select=33frFfOnW5A6Wmr939GoEQ

Granted I've never been to Thanh Long to have their famous garlic noodles, so I have no basis for comparison. But I've had garlic noodles at PPQ, Kim Thanh, Perilla, Red Crawfish just to name a few and ATG's garlic noodles pales in comparison. I've gone to Crustacean 5 years ago but I never ordered the garlic noodles and I don't remember it being memorable at all. 

When we opened the plastic container, there was no garlic aroma unless you placed the bowl under your nose and took a big whiff. 

An's garlic noodles were missing that al-dente and chewy texture because they were overcooked. It was as if it was previously cooked off-location and then reheated. Properly cooked noodles should also be able to maintain its shape but these noodles were choppy. Most importantly, the garlic noodles were missing that quintessential pungent but not overpowering garlicky butteryness both in aroma and in taste. It did have some garlic flavor but simply just not enough to make it the "famous" garlic noodles as its namesake states. 

On to the 2 P's - Pricing and Portion:

Ok, so we all know that most food trucks can be a little pricey but ATG's noodles were completely overpriced. When you're competing with other trucks who serve sandwiches with meat busting at the seams and hefty, mouth-watering fusion burritos, charging $7.50 for a fraction of the restaurant portion is not going to cut it; especially when it's just a bowl of starch made with inexpensive ingredients. 

1 Star for the garlic noodles
1 Star for the friendly service and accepting CC's

Sorry, ATG but I'll be rolling on by to the next truck when we meet again...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I was lured in by the long line. Possibly the second longest line at Off the Grid. 

It was $10 for the garlic noodles + a skewer (your choice of lemongrass chicken, beef, or pork?). They give a generous amount of noodles with your order, and its cooked with hefty portions of garlic and cheese! I wish they gave more meat though. :/
author: Jeanette S.

description:
Been to this food truck just once and I thought the food was okay. Got the shrimp over garlic noodles. The proportion of noodles to meat could have definitely been better. Even though the garlic noodles were quite good, the meat wasn't enough. Noticed this for the pork and beef servings as well.

On the positive side, staff was friendly and the wait time wasn't bad.
author: Zoher Z.

description: $9 Garlic noodles with Pork. I love this stuff. They give a decent amount of noodles but I expected a bit more for $9. The flavor is just about right, not too heavy garlic or butter, kind of like Perilla. The pork was really good. Reminds me of bulgogi for some odd reason. Always here when the food truck is in the area!
author: Benita M.

description:
Too expensive, too plain. 

Having had good food truck noodles in San Francisco, I thought An The Go would also deliver. Food truck prices can be steep, but ultimately you get something interesting and tasty. An The Go just left me feeling disappointed. Echoing other reviewers, the noodles are completely plain. Completely plain. No trace of vegetables, meat, herbs, or even pieces of chopped garlic. The noodles were garlicky sure, but overcooked and mushy. 

The pork skewer was flavorful, but on the dry side.

You might consider An-other option.
author: Augusto T.

description:
Lost in translation would be how I describe 'Ah The Go'.  Or should I say Lost in Transition in flavor from Crustaceans to the truck.

Garlic noodles is one of my all time favorite dishes. In fact Crustaceans is in my top five favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  The truck noodles just don't meet up to the fresh taste at the restaurant.  Don't get me wrong, still an acceptable lunch at Civic Center.   But light years away from the sheer awesomeness of getting it hot and fresh. This was more soft and lukewarm.

AN The Go,

Unfortunately I must say...  As Ms. Keyshia Cole sang:

But baby, I just kept holding "AN", I shoulda let you go

AN the Go

Shoulda let you go
I shoulda let you go
I should have let you go
Longtime ago..
author: Michael L.

description:
Garlic noodles! 

I was able to try their food truck through the Sactomofo event in Sacramento. They had a bit of a line about 20 minutes, but it was worth it.

I ordered the garlic noodle combo for $9, though I was severely tempted to get the larger combo with appetizer for $15. I was kind of expecting my noodles to come out oily, as it seems to happen a lot when I order garlic noodles in a lot of places but....to my surprise they were not! They actually were very tasty and I ended up liking it a lot. I also paired that up with their 5 spice pork skewer, which also tasted really good. I ended very satisfied with the food I orderied. :) Yums!
author: Mariah L.

description:
Overrated...This was the longest line in the food truck at Off the Grid Oakland, so you expect it to be the BEST right? 

Wrong!  I was a bit disappointed..."Garlic Noodles" are what they're known for, but the noodles were way too soft and did not have much flavor.  I want more garlic!  =P
author: Raquel Y.

description:
"An The Go" is more like "An The No!"  When I saw the menu, it sounded good especially when it referred to the same garlic noodle recipe as Crustacean and Thanh Long, but for $9.00, it was not worth it.  I had the garlic noodles with the Lemongrass Chicken skewer.  The chicken was like 3 bite sizes and the rest was a box full of spaghetti noodles with some hint of garlic.  

I also got the Vietnamese iced coffee for $3.50 which tasted nothing like it.  Instead, it tasted like a typical iced latte.  Usually when I get "real" Vietnamese coffee, I have to dilute it with additional ice and/or water as it's super strong and sweet and it takes me over an hour to finish drinking one because it's so strong, but theirs was nothing like it.  I chugged that drink in like 15 minutes!   Very disappointing!
author: Erica S.

description:
I'm mad about food trucks. One of my favorite things in all the world -- and the number of amazing food trucks in the bay area makes me one happy camper.

Every Tuesday, a whole host of them do a hoedown and so I have the luxury of trying a bunch of them out. I **normally** check the Yelp reviews prior to lining up, but An The Go looked so good, and really -- garlic noodles, lemongrass chicken, five spice pork, and a crispy Vietnamese roll for $14? I'm just going to go for it.

I wished I'd looked online first. 3 stars for a food truck is prolly an indication of why the line wasn't as long here as it was for the others.

First, the good: the crispy Viet roll was delicious. Fried to perfection, great dipping sauce and the contents had a phenomenal mix. But that was just an appetizer... the garlic noodles themselves were disappointing. It actually reminded me of pasta that someone had rolled around in garlic parmesan cheese. They put two skewers of the meat that you pick. I've not tasted such tasteless lemongrass chicken, and the five spices pork was only marginally better.

There are so many wonderful food trucks out there, with so many wonderful different dishes. This one, however, isn't one of them. Give it a miss and try whatever else is nearby.
author: James A.

description:
Writing this with mixed feelings since I try to be supportive of small businesses. This was my first time visiting An The Go and the review is for the 5-spice pork skewer with garlic noodles.

Positives - friendly staff.
Cons - quality of food was not bad, but the ratio of a full container of garlic noodles to 1 skewer of meat for $9 felt off.  A small side of greens, garnish, anything besides a sea of noodles in the container would have made the moment of opening the container less disappointing...
author: M G.

description: Ordered combo with garlic noodle, lemon grass beef, yuzu shrimp, fried crab dumpling    with peanut sauce.  Beef has no lemongrass flavor. Shrimp was good. Can't taste yuzu but shrimp was fresh and naturally sweet.  Peanut sauce for dumpling is greasy and not much peanut flavor.  Overall not good enough for almost $16 ( with tax)
author: Adalyn J.

description:
I got to try An the Go while at Off the Grid (Fort Mason) recently and thought that their food was okay - not great.

I ordered their famous garlic noodles with a grilled shrimp skewer. The price wasn't bad, I think $8-9? It was a generous portion of noodles, I actually didn't finish them all! They had a tasty garlic flavor, but I think it was more reminiscent of garlic powder than fresh garlic. The flavor just got bland for me halfway through. It needed some veggies for crunch and freshness, I think. The shrimp skewer on the other hand was really flavorful and cooked perfectly. I wish that it had come with two! 

I don't think that I'd order it again, just based off the lack of flavor. Perhaps if they added some stir fry veggies and cut back on the portion of noodles, I would entertain the idea of eating their food again.
author: Liz G.

description:
SactoMoFo 3

I was full already, but the garlic noodles smelled so good that I decided to give it a try. I was a bit wary because of the price. It was more than I wanted to pay. I didn't see any actual garlic, so I assume they use garlic powder instead. The noodles were also greasy. It was enough for two people, so I wish they offered a smaller size. I wasn't able to finish it. I ate my leftovers before going to the gym. I should've also known better because it didn't sit well.
author: Helen H.

description:
I don't understand the simplicity of this garlic noodles dish.  I've probably eaten from this place twice.  Once paying a high amount for very simple garlic noodles and meat on top of it.  There is no Vietnamese flair in this dish, I need the extra sides or condiments of vegetables or light sauce to eat it with.  It doesn't even seem Vietnamese seriously.  NO VEGETABLES.  WTF!

Totally not worth it, I'm surprised people actually buy food from here still. I'd much rather prefer O MI NINJA to this truck.  Much more balanced dishes and more traditional flavors.  The meat is alright and is the only reason why I'd give them a little credit.  I don't usually like simple dishes unless they are executed well and taste amazing.  I like food to be more complex with more elements if possible to keep the flavors interesting.  

An The Go, needs to GO.  Get the hell out of here!
author: Kenny P.

description:
Being a noodle truck, this isn't exactly aimed towards people like me who dislike starch heavy meals.

I tried their coconut shrimp.  It was adequate stuff.  'Tis what one expects when they order coconut shrimp, it didn't stand out from the pack for better or worse, but that is okay.  The sauce complimented the shrimp well.

__________

Conclusion:
Very edible fare.  Doesn't really excel, but it also doesn't disgust.
author: Jason S.

description:
tonight was the first night they rolled out @ OtG - Haight. For those of you who don't know the An family... well, they own Crustacean and Thanh Long. they're famous for their crab and garlic noodles galore! 

since it was their first food service tonight, it was a bit hectic. line was slow moving and they ran out of noodles. which then resulted to another 30min wait for them to hurry and make more. 

$7.50 for garlic noodles was a bit pricey for such a small portion. but it was still delish! and a small lemongrass chicken skewer was $2.50. not impressed because the chicken was a bit dry and it just didn't have the WOW factor. 

hopefully, after a bit more experience in the food truck business, things will get better. for now, I'll stick to their restaurants.
author: Ann T.

description:
An the go should really go.  An fast.  Just because you serve food from a roach coach doesn't give you license to peddle doo doo.  I went to the 'off the grid' event in Belmont yesterday.  An and his/her crew's advertising makes their 'famous fried noodles' sound sophisticated...like you're going to get a creative and tasty plate of food.  This is wrong. 

I tried the five spice pork fried noodles.  I haven't felt this screwed since I got drunk and passed out on Polk Street.  First, think Top Ramen.  After boiling the noodles, you throw them in the frying pan, then dump, pour and bast with garlic sauce.  Finally, find the cheapest pork shoulder you can, cook till tough, skewer, and marinate in Panda Express secret sauce.   Stuff all in a recyclable box and sell for $13.  Drive away before there are enough disgruntled customers to form a mob.  Repeat at next 'Off the Grid' event.  

There hasn't been much Mexican on Asian violence in California.  I can tell you, if it wasn't for Mrs. Nacho and little Nachito holding me back, there would have been last night.  Try a different roach coach.
author: Nacho L.

description:
We had a company party and invited a couple of food trucks.  When anyone ordered some of the garlic noodles I could smell it and worried that the garlic would be too much since it was a company party.

I braved up and had a bowl of the stir fried vegetables with the garlic noodles... It was delightfully delicious.. the garlic flavor was strong but it wasn't over powering and the garlic taste didn't linger in my mouth for hours.

I also tried the lemon grass chicken skewer it was GOOOOOD.  The noodles definitely taste better hot, I had a few bites and had to talk to some people so my noodles got a bit cold =(.

The people working the truck were EXTREMELY friendly and very chatty. Out of all the vendors we had they were the nicest and most fun to talk to. At the end of the day they even packed up some extra noodles for us in to go boxes and had to go bags.

Trucks like this make me believe in the food truck revolution.

My only suggestion would be their togo boxes need a minor upgrade.  They use the paper cardboardish ones... but for hot food closed tight... by the time i took it home the box was all soggy and ready to fall apart =(
author: Belinda T.

description: I went to Off the Grid at Civic Center for lunch and decided to try An the Go. I ordered the garlic noodle lunch combo which came with a lemon grass chicken skewer, grilled vegetables and a crispy spring roll. The service was friendly, so I wish I could be more complimentary about the food. Everything was pretty bland and tasted as if it was soaked in butter. Although the serving size was very large, I would not order this again. I also wish they had sriracha and soy sauce which may have helped with the flavor.
author: John L.

description: Let me start off with the customer service. It was amazing! The guy really took the time to talk to me and remember my name. However, the food was just decent. The garlic noodles were not that great and it's their main dish. The skewers were to die for and the crab puffs were amazing. I'd say stick to the meat.
author: Alex L.

description:
$7.50 for a big container of PLAIN garlic noodles? And an extra $2.50 for a tiny skewer of beef, chicken, or veggies?? Not worth it.

The flavor is strong - very strong garlic. Which wouldn't be bad if it was complimented with more meat or veggies. So you pretty much have to dish out the whole $10 for just a tiny skewer of meat. The noodles are really thick and soft/soggy - not really for me.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
The food: Garlic noodle combo with Beef and Shrimp and the crab side.

The price felt a bit much at 15ish dollar for the whole thing, but The garlic noodle was actually delicious! the amount of garlic was perfect and the side with the peanut sauce was delicious. The beef and shrimp was average. i would definitely try this truck again and maybe try the different protein. once again delicious noodles!
author: Peter V.

description: Didn't check these reviews before ordering. Didn't know it's 4shrimps only for $9. Noodles were OK. There's no vegetables or anything else. I was very disappointed
author: d h.

description: I didn't feel like having garlic noodles tonight, but I still got food from An the Go.  I ordered a lemongrass chicken skewer and a yuzu shrimp skewer.  It seemed like it took a long time to get my food, but that might be because it was so hot waiting in the sun.  My two skewers were served with some pickled vegetables.  I wasn't expecting the crunchy radish, carrots, & cucumber, but they were a welcome addition.  The chicken and shrimp were tasty and perfectly cooked.  Thanks!
author: Lorianne L.

description:
Ayyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy 
tasty noodles!
op 
op 
op 
op tastyyyy nooodles!

Great hot, ok cold.
author: Emily D.

description: This truck is delicious! omg!!  And fairly priced and you get A TON!  Holy moly!  I wanted the $14 combo because I thought you got a skewer and another side (crab puffs), but when I got to the window he said I got TWO skewers...so I got 2 skewers (chicken and shrimp), 2 crab puffs and garlic noodles.  Holy moly!  For $14, I'd say that's a deal in SF!!  It was a lot of food, so I was sure I would be saving some for later...umm it was so good, that did not happen!  Everything was so well flavored and cooked, thumbs up!  I will definitely be going back again!!
author: Jenna L.

description:
If I had read the Yelp reviews before going here, I would've gone to a different food truck. Don't be deceived by the long lines.

These are not foodie noodles with bits of real garlic, scallions, and other seasonings and vegetables in them, as I had imagined they would be. It's just plain rice noodles (I think) dusted with some garlic powder. So no actual garlic. I shouldn't expect so much from a food truck, I guess. The chicken skewer was just fine though.

The line is not very well-managed either at Off the Grid. There is one person who both takes orders and passes out the food when it's done. This just further delays things since you have one person doing virtually everything except for the cooking. It would be more efficient to hire a second person to pass out the orders while the first one takes it. Given the popularity of the place, they should have enough income to do so. A disappointment.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
For $9 plus tax ($9.80 total), you're not getting much value. A bunch of garlic noodles (pretty plain looking, but lots of garlic flavor), no garnishes, no vegetables and a small skewer of thin meat adds up to an underwhelming experience. I used to help out with a food truck and we gave a lot more bang for the buck.

The noodles themselves were a little overdone, but not too much. It was somewhat oily, but I don't mind that in my food. The meat was pretty nicely seasoned and grilled but it turned out that they gave me chicken instead of the five spice pork that I ordered. The food itself I would have given about 3.5 stars, but because it's pricey for what you get I cannot recommend this truck. My friends actually warned me before not to buy from them but alas I forgot their warning.
author: Si L.

description:
Got the $14 dinner combo, which includes: 

- an order of garlic noodles 
- your choice of two skewers 
- your choice of either one fried egg roll or two crab puffs 

Sounds like a good deal, no? 

For my two skewers, I chose the lemongrass beef and the shrimp, and got two crab puffs. 

Unfortunately, I didn't enjoy anything I ordered. The noodles were overly soft and just not flavorful. What garlic? Both skewers were dry; the beef was pretty tough. The crab puffs were *tiny*. Each was about the size of my thumb. That a full order of crab puffs is 4 pieces, for which they charge $6, seems ridiculous. 

Keep in mind that I always want to like what I eat. I dislike writing negative reviews because going out to eat is such a subjective experience, and for all I know, I could've showed up on a bad day. Maybe that's just what happened here.
author: Le V.

description:
Love the food 
awesome service 
quick and easy 
garlic noodles-Decent portion even had left over for next day 
Crab rangoon very tasty worth every penny 
Beef and shrimp skewers were juicy 
Left with full tummy definitely will follow this food truck everywhere 
Need one to park in front of my work spot
author: Mochi A.

description:
Finally had the chance to try the garlic noodles.  Got it with the beef skewer and an order of the crispy rolls.

I know there are mixed reviews about price for the noodles, but they really do give you quite a bit of the noodles.  I was able to share an order with my 4 year old son, my wife and myself.  We did have other truck food, but definitely it was big enough to share.  I really liked the size and the texture of the crispy rolls.  They weren't too greasy and held it's crispy texture despite not being eaten for about 20 mins.  I did think the price was a little steep for two of them

Would definitely get the food again.  My son loves noodles, so this is a good way to keep him satisfied.  You probably will need some more food if you are sharing though.
author: Josh L.

description:
Yes, we were drawn by the mention of Thanh Long and Crustacean.  Of course, we got garlic noodles, and we added pork skewers.  Noodles had a good bite, weren't very saucy, and had a reasonably amount of garlic, but I prefer super strong garlic. Pork was sweet, well seasoned, pretty easy to get off the skewers.

It wasn't cheap, but it satisfied our garlic noodle craving for the night.
author: Marilyn H.

description: Seems like many reviewers are disappointed with the meat to noodles ratio. They should try the vegetarian garlic noodles because there are plenty of good, fresh vegetables over the noodles. I'm always satisfied & happy with the proportion of veggies to noodles. Plus the garlic noodles are darn tasty. Nice people working in the truck, fast service, price is fine.
author: Wan T.

description:
Checked out this food truck while at OTG. I tried their famous garlic noodle combo. I was kind of disappointed when I tasted the noodles. The flavoring of the noodle was very nice; however, the noodle didn't taste very good. It felt like they used regular pasta noodles. It would have been nice if the noodles were a better consistency. I got the pork skewer which was the best part of the combo meal. The pricing of $9 was definitely not appropriate for the meal. 

Hopefully, their garlic noodles will improve over time...
author: Edward Y.

description:
I couldn't decide what to have for lunch, I just hopped on Muni headed down towards the Ferry Building.  The bus passed by UN Plaza and I saw food trucks and decided to hop off any try a Food Truck I haven't had before.  The line for Senor Sisig was too long but An The Go was much more bearable.

I ordered the Lunch Combination of Garlic Noodles with Lemongrass Beef Skewer.  The container was full of noodles, which was good and not very garlicky and not really greasy.  However, there was only one skewer, 4 pieces of meat.

Not really bang for the buck and I would not eat at this food truck again. Sorry!
author: Allen C.

description:
Wow!  So heppy there is a food truck for Garlic Noodles.

The best and so delicious.  Good value too.

My tummy is always happy after eating some Ang Family Garlic Noodles!

Everything is terrific!
author: Daniel P.

description:
How this food truck stays in business is beyond me. I had them at the Edgewood Eats gathering and Hubs got their garlic noodles with a chicken skewer. The portions here are outrageously small for what they're charging. $7.50 for a small portion of boiled egg noodles tossed in what tasted like fake butter and garlic powder. Pathetic. The noodles themselves aren't very tasty - definitely on the gummy tasteless side and the garlic flavor was nothing compared the yummy noodles you can get at their stand along restaurants. Greasy gummy mess. Yeche! A skewer for nearly three dollars... 10+ dollars wasted at the worst food truck there was. For an additional 5 bucks on top of what I spent, I could have gotten a lobster roll.... At least the base ingredients are worth something and go a farther way to justify the cost. 

An the Go, Fool me once. Shame on you. You won't fool me twice. I'm staying far away from this truck! It's nothing like the food they serve at the restaurants! I'm taking my 10 bucks and getting 3 Chairman Baos instead... at least pork belly actually costs something! Noodles? Dirt cheap. Random garlic flavoring? Probably just as cheap. Definitely does not justify the $7.50... maybe $3-4. Definitely not $7.50. Tastewise? Not even worth $3.
author: Vicky L.

description:
I hate to give a low rating and usually don't post, but felt compelled to let people know our experience, and maybe the folks on the truck will take note and improve. 

Took the family out to a food truck court. Both kids love noodles. They eat them at home, they eat them when we go out, they ask for the noodle shop when requesting a restaurant. 

Well, they didn't like these noodles. They were pretty soft (I'd say a bit on the mushy side) and while I liked the garlic flavor, the noodles themselves were not something I would eat either. 

The meat on top was a small chicken skewer about 4 inches long and thin. Not much meat. Then a whole basket of soft noodles with garlic seasoning - for 9 Bucks? Seriously?  

The kids ate the chicken skewer, nibbled at the noodles, and then asked if there was anything else to eat when we got home. Most of the $9 got dumped in the trash.  

2 stars for the flavor. They could improve if they offer a better value.
author: G P.

description: Who the hell puts cheese in garlic noodles and also not disclose it? Ridiculous. Be safe people that have allergies. They should be shut down.
author: David S.

description:
Had the $9 combo with garlic noodles and lemongrass chicken skewer. I should have read the yelp reviews. I agree with the guy who wrote, 'less carbs, more meat'. C'mon, can I have a second skewer? I'll trade in some noodles. How about half a skewer?

Noodles are better at the restaurants. Something is missing.
author: Steve L.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for a while now and finally got to at Off the Grid in Burlingame.

Ordered 2 combo plates and thought the food was just ok. Nothing great at all. Noodles were way too oily and a bit mushy.  Chicken skewer was under cooked, beef skewer was overcooked almost jerkey like, pork skewer was just ok but I did like the shrimp.  $25 for both plates. Way overpriced!

I will say the service was good. The guy at the window was really nice but won't be coming back for the food.
author: lynn a.

description:
Currently on a roll of reviewing Bay Area food trucks and this one is definitely one of my favorite! The owners of the An the Go trucks also own Crustacean and other popular Vietnamese restaurants in the Bay. The food here is super good, super rich and unfortunately, super bad for your diet! Oh well...

It's all about the Garlic Noodles at An the Go! They are amazing! I love ordering the Garlic Noodles combo with the Lemongrass Beef skewer and Lemongrass Chicken Skewer. The beef and chicken are always well seasoned and tender, never overlooked. An the Go's Imperial Rolls are hands down my favorite! I loved the filling of ground chicken and vermicelli noodles. The Crab Puffs are also rich and delicious! 

You can always find An the Go at most Off the Grid weekly markets. Lines can be quite long but they are usually fast at getting orders out. Employees have always been friendly. Prices are reasonable. Check them out!!!
author: Paul C.

description:
This is the second 1 star I'm giving out. 

I got this with a coworker thinking garlic noodles could potentially be really awesome. The combo is $9 which consists of a pile of noodles with garlic powder (I don't see any actual garlic in it) and a strip of meat on top. If this were $6 instead of $9, it would be 2 stars.

The other food trucks that come to this location on other days have been consistently good.
author: Thomas C.

description: We frequented ATG over the past few years and used to love it.  Unfortunately, there has been a steady decline in the quality and taste of food.  Last visit sealed the deal, something has gone awry with the food preparation there.  We ordered the shrimp skewer over garlic noodles, and the veggies over noodles.  The veggies were overcooked and also soggy -- black wilted broccoli, and soggy noodles.  My friend's shrimp had an "off" flavor, and more wilted noodles.  This is the second bad meal there in row, so we're off the Grid, and off ATG.
author: Merry B.

description:
Run by the same people as Thanh Long and Crustacean, I was excited to see that they now have their own food truck when I was at Off The Grid recently.  It's been years since I've gone back to Thanh Long, but I've always remembered thinking that their garlic noodles were pretty tasty.  Now that they have a truck, talk about a convenient way to get some of their noodles An The Go (har har har).

Being that there was a few of us there, we decided that instead of getting our own orders, we would just share instead.  To give ourselves a bit of variety without going overboard, we decided to get only one order of their garlic noodles (of course) along with two of their skewers - the Lemongrass Chicken and the BBQ Pork.  After all, we had to save space for the other trucks!

When our to-go box came out, we popped it open to find a sizable mound of noodles along with our two skewers.  Although the noodles looked somewhat similar to what I had before, the taste wasn't that familiar.  Granted, it's been a while since I've had the stuff, but it didn't seem to be as garlic-y and buttery as I remember or would have liked.  It was still pretty decent though, but it could have packed a little more punch and it just didn't seem as good as what you get at Thanh Long.  As for the skewers, they were perfectly fine, but not unique either.  The meat was cooked well on both, and the lemongrass chicken flavor was solid.

From what I could see from the orders ahead of us, adding a skewer or two will get you a little more noodles in your box, but you might want to do it anyways for some meat.  It'll be filling either way though.  I'd say the truck is worth trying if the line isn't too crazy, since the taste will vary slightly by the day and batch.  It's a nice food truck option, but not as good as what you could probably find in their restaurants.
author: Mike L.

description: I saw a long line for these noodles and was excited to try them. I expected them to be dense, chewy and delicious. Instead, they were like greasy, overcooked spaghetti. I didn't see any asian influence there. Wouldn't recommend it and would go out of my way to eat somewhere else.
author: Sara S.

description:
$7.50 for a bowl of really, really greasy garlic noodles...Nothing special about the noodles and made me feel ill afterwards.

I paid another $2.50 for 4 little really greasy shrimps. No Thanks.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Similar to Paul V., I got the beef skewer combo (with garlic noodle).
It was two small skewers and a whole mound of garlic noodle.

The garlic noodle was actually TOO MUCH for me at the time. I think I could have used more protein in order to balance it out. Or maybe some bread to soak up the heavy butter from the noodles?

I was excited to see a food truck by An, but it's kind of a let down to have "Crustaceans" and "Thanh Long" plastered on the side of a truck and not have any drunken crab or anything similar.
author: Chris C.

description:
An The Go is all about its strong, pungent Garlic Noodles that will wreck your breath the whole day. I like their noodles: strong, garlicy, delicious. I ordered the $9 combo with having no expectations to the Beef skewer. But it also actually tasted more than it just sitting on the griller. The combo may be a little too steep in price but the whole thing is actually filling. 

What I like to do is order one to go, bring it at home, and toss some sauteed veggies and grilled salmon on the side. Mmm
author: Paul V.

description: Complete rip off. A small pile of what tastes like over cooked spaghetti noodles and 4 small shrimp for $10. Taste and quality would be unimpressive even at half the price. It tasted like something that I would make when I'm falling down drunk at 3am with nothing in the fridge. I have had microwave ramen noodles that were better. If I could give zero stars, I would.
author: Nader E.

description:
The obligatory side-order at every An Family restaurant is the garlic noodles.  Now you can get them without having to shell out extra dough for that dungeness crab as a main dish (which is not bad way to spend your money, however).  Just as tasty and addicting as in their restaurant, but cheaper than their restaurant prices!

I've ordered the garlic noodles with some of the skewers they offer, but I'd suggest skipping the skewers altogether and just ordering a hefty order of the garlic noodles on their own.
author: Erich D.

description:
The biggest craze right now are these food trucks. Passed by Walgreens and An The Go was serving lunch off Misson street.

I honestly didn't know if garlic noodles and one stick of meat skewer was worth $10.
