I could go down one block and get the same order with a little more meat, and a couple of pieces of broccoli, for nearly the same price at Perilla's.  Everything was individually priced.  So if you wanted an extra skewer, it'll cost you.

BUT....An's noodles are pretty tasty.  Lots of garlic with a slight sweetness to it. The noodles alone will expand in your belly and make you full. The pork skewer was ok but nothing to write about.

The guy behind the counter was SUPER COOL and CHIPPER!  He could have sold me an egg roll or two ($2.50 each)...anything really, and I'd buy it just cuz he made me feel happy!

Price-wise, it's pretty expensive for "TRUCK" food so no 4 stars. But I ate the whole thing....and my breath was hummin' GARLIC for the rest of the day. And burping up garlic in meetings, IS NOT COOL.

GARLIC NOODLES, WOOT WOOT!
author: Diana M.

description:
$7.50 for a small heap of garlic noodles that would cost you, like, what, 7.5 cents if you made them on your own? $2.50 extra for each teeny tiiiny little meat skewer with maybe 25 cents' worth of meat? You've got to be ****ing kidding me.

The garlic noodles feel OK going down, but are soooo heavy on the garlic that it'll leave you absolutely dehydrated no matter how much water you gulp down, not to mention an aftertaste (and totally funky breath) that'll linger for hours. The meat skewers are OK enough - if you can get over swallowing down their extra cost, on top of the small fortune you already paid for the noodles.

If you're at a food truck festival like Off the Grid or Moveable Eats, save your $10 and get more bang for the buck elsewhere.
author: Vincent L.

description:
I was flying home to San Diego and saw An The Go's food truck stopped there at the terminal. I got a few tacos from Senor Sisig, which were awesomely tasty, but that's not the best part and Senor isn't who this review is about. 

Rather, the best part was that I had this nagging feeling in the back of my head that I should go back out to the other truck, An the Go, and peer in. Garlic noodles? Soup? I was intrigued. No, not soup, but still the best effin' thing I've eaten in my 47 years of living on this planet. 

I usually attribute such superlatives to being so hungry and starved. But no, I just had tacos, so it had to be the garlicky noodles. I just don't get people who considered these noodles to be disappointing. I savored my bad breath for the next two days more as a reminder of the lingering memories of a delicious hot serving of noodles, in a cardboard tray no less. It's one of the times I've made the "O" face when eating, it was that good.
author: Michael D.

description:
If you've ever strolled around an Asian market and made your way down the packaged noodle aisle, you would most likely find a bright yellow bag by the name of "Lucky Me Pancit Canton." This is like the Filipino version of Top Ramen except it has a packet of dry seasoning, and another packet containing lard and soy sauce. 

Why bring up Lucky Me, you ask? Well, An the Go's garlic noodles is much like this instant packet of pancit canton (Filipino version of the chow mein). An the Go's is pretty basic. The noodles were a bit dry and whenever I think of noodles, the greasier...the better. They could've also used extra garlic; I barely tasted the garlic flavor.  Plus, there's a whole lot of noodle compared to the little meat you get from a single skewer. I was out of lemongrass chicken by the time I got halfway through my noodles. They give you a tray of noodles which is a good amount for $7, but consider getting your meat elsewhere from a different vendor since they do skimp on that.
author: May D.

description: I saw An The Go at the Hiller Aviation Museum on Wednesday, and decided to give them a try since I love garlic noodles. When you go to the window to place your order, they have the business card of Crustacean and another restaurant displayed, so you start off with high expectations with the quality of the garlic noodles. I ordered the Beef w/Garlic Noodles ($9, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/an-the-go-san-francisco?select=I28RdCbr4O3YSYqL3W7X7w#I28RdCbr4O3YSYqL3W7X7w), which came with one skewer of a 4 small squares of beef. They gave you a good amount of garlic noodles, but sadly, they weren't very garlicky, or even flavorful for that matter. Since I also purchased something from The Chairman, I grabbed some sriracha from them and had to use a large quantity on my noodles for them to have any sort of taste. I thought the noodles were pricey for $9, and like other reviewers, wish I had paid closer attention to the yelp reviews before I decided to eat here! Use your $9 somewhere else, like KoJa!
author: Amy D.

description:
I discovered An the Go's food truck at the Treasure Island Flea Market today, and choosing between Le Truc and 51st State, I made the wrong choice of going with An the Go.

I ordered the famous garlic noodles ($7.50) with the add-on of one lemongrass chicken skewer ($2.50) from the friendly server. The skewer was ok; the lemongrass chicken was juicy and moist. However, the garlic noodles were a huge let down; they were soggy and stuck together. I was hungry and tried to finish the noodles despite how bad they tasted, but I felt nauseous and threw the other half away.
author: Diana B.

description: One of the best food trucks in the Bay! The best garlic noodles EVER! Looking forward to catching this truck again.
author: Barrie B.

description:
Went to OTG Upper Haight again last night.  I hit up the usuals...Eat Curbside, 51st State, Senor Sisig, and Eat Cupkates.  But the star of the show last night was An The Go.  This truck is the "rill dill."  (inside joke)  I got the garlic noodles, the lemongrass chicken and beef skewers, and the 5-spice pork skewer.

First off, the garlic noodles (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wxitWND4sjRCKBpaNq32Kw?select=hBYXZaVDATY8uEfh2AkskA).  Yes, they were good.  I kinda think of them as an advertisement for Crustacean and Thanh Long.  All that's missing is the crab.

The skewers...oh man.(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wxitWND4sjRCKBpaNq32Kw?select=rsDKHzUKpTeaK7aJexWTYQ)  These are a must try.  Tons and tons of flavor.  It says lemongrass, you get lemongrass.  It says 5-spice, you get 5-spice.  I definitely liked the pork more than the chicken.  It had more of that BBQ feel to it.  But really, you can't go wrong.

Overall, an excellent meal.  If I had a bottle of 333 to go with it, it would've been perfect.  The truck is like 2 weeks new, so if you see it don't even think twice.  Get in line and enjoy!
author: Joe M.

description:
Friend ordered garlic noodle + 5 spice pork skewer combo at Off the Grid, and we both thought it was not worth 9 bucks.

Skewer: not too bad, but not too great. Pretty much something you can get at any other Vietnamese restaurant. It was a bit too salty for me, and kinda small.

Garlic Noodle: one word - OVERPRICED. OVERLY OVERPRICED. It's basically noodles with garlic powder and oil? I mean...it doesn't taste bad. But come on...$7.50 for that??? I would cry if that was my money. I still felt bad for my friend who paid 9 bucks for the meal.

Not worth it.
author: Janey L.

description: Garlic noodles are good but needs more crispyness and less "mush". The shrimp skewers are ok. For $9, I think it's more like a $6-$7 item.
author: Ben L.

description:
Today I went to An The Go in Bishop Ranch in San Ramon! I order the Garlic noodles w. Yuzu shrimp skewer (4 shrimps) for $9, Coconut Prawns (3) w. tangy orange dipping sauce for $5, and a Sprite for $1!

Breakdown Review:

Garlic Noodles - AMAZING! They was a nice blend between a buttery and Garlic taste. They were soft (which made it easy to cut thru for easy sharing) & they were a perfect temperature to eat right away (not too hot, not too cold). If you've ever had thanh long in SF or crustaceans and order their garlic noodles, its the same exact taste! The shrimps on the skewers were amazing also and well cooked thru! They gave enough noodles for the money spent, I really enjoyed it!

Coconut Prawns - They were good, but without the sauce they are nearly flavorless. I can honestly say I expected at LEAST 4 prawns, when I opened the box and only seen 3 I was disappointed but still in all they were great!

Sprite - could have been colder lol


Bishop Ranch is in a business park center so it was alot of people due to lunch rush hour BUT the service was very quick! I waited no more than 10 mins..

OVERALL:

I would HIGHLY suggest having this for lunch and I myself will DEFINITELY eat here again =)
author: Nelly C.

description:
Disappointing. Menu looks appetizing and they entice you by mentioning Crustacean and Thanh Long but sadly, all you get is a box of greasy noodles topped with some garlic. 

We got the noodles to go and by the time we arrived home, the bottom of the bag was soaked in grease which means the grease leaked out from the to go container! And then it got all over my table, my hands... what a mess! Ridiculous! 

The prices are outrageous for a box of noodles. And throwing on some extra extra small side of meat (additional charge!) makes it oh so much better? Terrible. Waste of money. I'm mad I stood in line and waited for that crap.
author: L L.

description:
I tried their food when they were at the Larkspur Landing location on Sunday.  I ordered the Garlic Noodles, Spice Pork Skewer, and the Vietnamese Crispy Roll.  The aroma from the truck was mouth watering and I was so looking forward to trying their food.  When my number was called I onlly got my Garlic Noodles and Pork Skewer.  They forgot my Vietnamese Crispy Roll.  I let it go since they gave me back the wrong change (more than I was suppose to get), which worked out.

Like the other reviewer, the noodles were good but it was a lot and little bit of meat.  Maybe next time I'll order 2 or 3 skewers.  After eating it for a while, my fiancee and I got tired of it.  It was good overall and the portion was huge for the price, but it did lack a bit of flavor.  

I'll be back to try something else.
author: Linda M.

description:
Paying $9 for more noodles than even a fatty like myself can comfortably eat, with just a single skewer of meat perched on top? Why would anyone do that?

I guess not many people do. I got to the Truck Stop just as the lunch rush began, and while the other two trucks had respectable lines, An the Go had nobody. I should have taken that as a sign, but I just wanted to get something quick. 

After waiting longer than I would have expected, I got my box, full of garlic(ish) noodles. They are yummy for the first dozen or so forkfulls, but finishing them off is painful. I'm a big guy, but I felt icky afterwards. 

I would prefer to pay $6.50 for half the amount of noodles, or I would also like to see some sort of vegetable involved, without having to go for the full-on veggie option.
author: Alex K.

description:
An the Go is famous for their garlic noodles (7.50) and guess what i got? 
. yep. coconut prawns (5) and crispy vietnamese egg roll (2.50) no doubt noodles would taste good for $$ but worthiness was relative 

locale: otg@un plaza

menu: garlic noodles (7.50) various  skewers, (2.50) coconut prawns(5) crispy egg roll (2.5) drinks (2-3)

sampling: coconut prawns(5)
-3 pieces of prawns wasn't that crispy, seem kind of doughy, authentic  coconut taste on the outside. dipping sauce  provided. 3 stars
-crispy vietnamese egg roll (1/2.5)
egg roll only 4 inches long? insides a tasty mix of meat and veggies. sweet & sour sauce provided. 4 stars

foodnotes:
-an started slowly but lines started to form.
-service was quick and courteous, food came quickly.
-garlic noodles portion seem small (7.50)
-portions small, think gourmet dining, tapas.
author: Victor G.

description:
I agree with Betty! Garlic noodles on wheels....Oh Yeah! I decided to give it a try even after reading some of the reviews. I was afraid that I was going to get greasy noodles (I didn't), small beef skewer (I didn't), greasy shrimp (I didn't). Maybe I got them on a good day? Who knows...

You obviously can't compare the quality to the actual dining experience but hey, they are a doorstep away and yes you will have to pay the price for the convenience. 

Downside is: I have garlic breath! Stay away Vamps!! ;)
author: Carla F.

description:
I feel I have to update my last 4-star review of An The Go.  Since the review, I have been two more times.  It is by far one of the most delicious items that I've had at Moveable Feast.

Don't know if I was full the last time, or if the other things that I had eaten earlier destroyed my taste buds - but my first review said "good, not great."  NOT ANYMORE!  This has become a go-to, and something I've been craving lately.  I hit them up on Twitter to see when they'll be back in the Jo.  But no reply :/

5-stars for the garlic noodles, and kababs.
author: Joel V.

description:
When it comes to food truck meets (in this case Off The Grid: Oakland), my friend has come up with the ultimate strategy in finding the best food: CHOOSE THE LONGEST LINE!!! 

When we first got to OTG the line at An The Go was INSANE. In fact, I was able to go to another truck, wait in line, order, and almost finish eating before my friend was even able to order. When my friend finally came back with 2 orders of the garlic noodle (one beef, one pork) I was SUPER EXCITED, that is, until I finally took a bite.

I love noodles, in fact some of my co-workers call me the noodle king, but even the noodle king could not show any love for these noodles. The noodles were super soggy, stuck together like they had not been properly cooked, and tasted like they had gone through a butter beating. As soon as I consumed some of the bland garlic noodles I felt my stomach shaking. The skewer was far superior to the noodles but even that was only alright. My friend took 3-4 bites of his noodles and threw the rest away, while I finished nearly 1/2 before I couldn't take it anymore. 

Overall I would have rated this a 2 star meal, but for 9$ for something I feel should only charged $5 I was very disappointed -_-. If you go to a food truck meet and An The Go is there, do yourself a favor and spend your money elsewhere.
author: Eddie K.

description: Hubby ordered the lemongrass beef skewer  with garlic noodles ($9) and 5-spice pork skewer with garlic noodles ($9).  I love the garlic noodles; I couldn't seem to get enough of it.  However, I don't think it's a great value for money...especially for a food truck.  It's way overpriced!  Final verdict? Skip it...unless you're really craving for garlic noodles.
author: Janice T.

description: Really it was very disappointing, yes expensive for two skewers over noodles and two fried won tons for $14, but I wouldn't have minded as much if the noodles weren't grossly over cooked and really, really soggy.  I threw them out, ate the crab wontons (they were OK) and my chicken and pork skewers (fair at best).  Sorry guys, your menu is too short not to be amazing, and if you have graphics of noodles all over your truck, you need to learn how to cook them.
author: Eric J.

description:
I was soooo looking forward to experiencing their food truck at Off The Grid in Belmont...disappointed!

For $9.00 I got a box of lukewarm noodles, not even garlicky, not the least bit.  And to make it worse the noodles were mushy and over cooked - yuck!  The 5spice pork skewer was so not 5 spice and did not impart any kind of discernible Asian flavor - just sad pork meat on a stick jammed on top of mushy noodles.   Epic fail!  Threw box into trash! :( 

Thank god for my old goto - Hiyaa was at OTG Belmont!  Trucked on over and got delicious garlicky noodles with crispy sticky spicy chicken - oh, yeah!  That's the ticket !  :)

So I'm very very very sorry to give this place a star - but I'm gonna give Hiyaa FIVE!
author: Charlie B.

description: When I found out Crustacean and Than Long had a food truck I was so excited! I love the garlic noodles. Was expecting a good meal but was disappointed.  For $10 you get the garlic noodles and a skewer.  I got the Lemongras Beef Skewer. One tiny skewer that I could finish right away, so I was left with a whole lot of garlic noodles which didn't have that moist buttery texture but a dry, gooey like pasta that left me unsatisfied. The beef skewer was dry and tough to eat.  If I wanted to order another skewer that was another $2.50 in addition to what I ordered.  Noodles were pretty bland such a disappointment since the garlic noodles at Than Long are divine.Pretty steep.  I also tried the coconut prawns and for $5 you get 3 deep fried prawns that were a little bit too burnt and crispy.  The dipping sauce was good but either than that pretty bland.  It was an over-priced meal with the quality and taste of the food not being a redeeming factor so it is probably something I would not get again.
author: Maria M.

description:
I looove garlic noodles!  So when I found out that they were going to be at Truck Stop today, I hopped on over for lunch.  Line was long and there is a bit of a wait.  I think it's because they only have one window for ordering and picking up as opposed to the indian truck next door.

I ordered the garlic noodles and coconut shrimp.  They packed up the noodles to the brim of the small round container. Coconut shrimp came in 3's.  Noodles were garlicky and very good.  Too bad there isn't any veggies or sides - which you have to order separately.  Shrimp was yummy.  A plus is that they accept credit cards. 

They are a tad expensive but you do get a lot of noodles for the price.  At least much more than what you would get for the same price or more at Perilla's and Unicorn's (two places where I used to get my garlic noodles but have since stopped because they over charged and underdelivered - yes they upped the price and gave out less).
author: Wendy H.

description: This was one of those d'oh!  I should have yelped it first experiences ... when my brother told me that one of the trucks at Moveable Feast was a garlic noodle truck, I was thinking it'd be a great opportunity to try garlic noodles like one of my friends has been raving about ... but of course, she's talking about "real" garlic noodles up in The City served with luscious crab, not the pile of somewhat garlicky noodles with a skewer of 4 sad little shrimp.  Oh, well.  My dogs enjoyed the left-over noodles ...
author: Susan Y.

description:
Have had An the Go at Edgewood Eats twice.  I didn't know anything about the truck when we had their garlic noodles the first time and I commented to a friend that they tasted just like the noodles I had at Crustacean.  Never mind that its been ages since I've eaten at Crustacean.  That's how memorable their noodles are.  Then I find out that they're associated.  Fancy that!

I also had their pork, chicken and beef skewers.  I'd have to say that the chicken was the best.

While their noodles are good, without the skewers, they were pretty boring. Yes, they were garlicky and good, but one single flavor profile can only hold you attention for so long.  Yes, you can add veggies and meat for an extra price, but for $7.50, the noodles should be able to stand on their own.  

As for value, it was pretty non-existent. $7.50 for noodles AND $2.50 for meat and veggies. Hell, I could get better chow mein for half that price.
author: Judi M.

description: The guys running this truck are awesome. Come to find out I can't have any of the plates because of a selfish allergy, so they gave me a FREE box of garlic noodles. I'm not saying everyone allergic to shrimp gets free food, but they were just so cool about it with me and made my day.
author: Ashley E.

description: Tried their garlic noodle for the first time. It was alright but I've had a lot of garlic noodle in my life time. $9 was a bit much for the portion and the taste.
author: Kristina L.

description:
I was afraid that I would get to yelp and see an inflated rating for ATG because of their name, but the 3 star average pretty much nails it for me too. Thanks yelp for being so consistent.

Saw ATG at the Treasure Island flea market today and seeing their lineage (i.e. crustacean, Thanh Long), it was a no brainer to try the garlic noodles. I also tried one beef and one pork skewer. 

The garlic noodles were just average. As soon as I tried them, I immediately thought that as food trucks 'food' goes, this is just one item that doesn't translate well (thanks michael l.) from the restaurant to the street. The flavor was decent, just not enough garlic (how ironic). But the downfall was the texture. They were just soggy and limp. Just not the way a good garlic noodle should be. Coupled with the cost ($7.50) and it was a bit disappointing.

The skewers on the other hand were both very tasty. The lemongrass on the beef and the 5 spice on the pork were both flavorful and tender. The meats were both grilled nicely with some light charring on the outside. Price was a bit high ($2.5 a skewer for about 4 pieces of meat per skewer).

Overall it wasn't food truck 'food' that I would definitely get again as soon as I see it.
author: Dom L.

description:
Someone from the Tran family totally needs to start a Vietnamese food truck in the Castro, "Street Tran", for the obvious name double entendre!  So finally a Vietnamese food truck that doesn't focus on the Vietnamese sandwich angle and doesn't offer a grain of rice.  I love that the centerpiece is the yummy noodles and that the proteins are an after thought, though still worthy.

Garlic Noodles: Since they are the signature, I had high expectations!  Very garlicky, like to the point where it actually feels spicy.  Soft, semi-thick noodles provided a good starchy base though they could have been slightly thinner to suit my tastes.

Lemongrass Beef Skewer: Probably the tastiest of the skewers.  Good amount of char and held the marinade well.

Lemongrass Chicken Skewer: Thin cuts of chicken with lots of lemongrass flavor, also a good char factor.  I'm inherently a beef fan, so it was good but not my tops.

5-Spice Pork Skewer: Not sure what cut of the pig this was from, but the texture reminded me of dark meat chicken.  Wasn't wowed by the meat or the spices.  Probably at the bottom of the skewer list.

Vietnamese Crispy Roll: I've had better.  There was a weird tendency for the wrapper to come off during a bite revealing the cylindrical meatball innards.  I prefer the smaller, denser version you typically get in rice noodle bowl at Vietnamese restaurants.  This was like an egg-rolled shaped Imperial roll.

Coconut Prawn: Probably the least value oriented of all the dishes with only 3 shrimp for $5.  Über -tasty with coconut shreds melded on through the magic of deep frying.  I know the mango salsa pairing has been done to death, but I still enjoyed it.
author: Adam B.

description:
Oh my goodness, where do I even start???  An the Go has the best garlic noodles I have ever tasted, hands down.  I ordered them with a lemongrass chicken skewer - so tasty and flavorful.  I had so much leftover garlic noodle, that I had it for lunch the next day - great portion sizes!  I hate going to places that skimp and barely give me enough food!

I would definitely recommend coming here with a friend or two, and ordering the different skewers so you can taste each one.
author: Sonya T.

description:
Pretty limited selection of food. But with food this good, do you really need a whole lot of choices? 

It should be required that when you step up to this truck, you order the garlic noodles ($7.50). Simple yet damn good? Yup. Their skewers are great too ($2.50). 

An The Go is definitely worth checking out.
author: John B.

description: Not a fan. Maybe I just don't "get" the overcooked garlic noodle thing. To me they didn't even have any garlic flavor, you can just tell that they were coated in some sort of something. The chicken I got on top was really small and sad too. I literally threw it out and had to go to another food truck. I understand why there's no line here. For the price you can definiekty get something better. I hate writing negative reviews but I just really really did not like this food truck
author: mackenzie e.

description:
I've died and gone to garlic noodle heaven. The garlic noodles were ON THE SPOT tonight! I could smell and taste the garlicky-buttery goodness on the noodles. It was seasoned well, and every bite was bursting with flavor. Yum! 

While I did not like the noodles at Thanh Long the ones at An the Go were yummy-omg-deliciousness!

A skewer of meat for $2.50 is a bit pricey, but so is $7.50 for a box of noodles, but hey if there's a demand, why not.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Doh!  I should have read the reviews first!  Big pile of noodles with 4 shrimp on top...really.  Please tell me that this is what I am going to get so I can order another skewer or something.  Now I need to figure out how to get the overbearing garlic taste out of my mouth.

Regards,

Gypped
author: Jon T.

description:
UM, ok, this was another one of those disappointing overpriced choices.

My buddy and I each ordered the garlic noodles (at $9.00 a pop!!!); one of us had it with the five-spice pork, and the other had it with the shrimp.

There's no rocket science to the noodles, though they are kind of mushy and taste like they've been dunked in garlic butter...that's it!! ...and it was the kind of mushy gummy texture in which you needed lots of water to wash it down!

Then, they place a skewer of meat on top; both my buddy and I each had five morcels of meat on the skewer. No rocket science here, nor any WOW-factor, either! I didn't even taste any five-spice in the pork!

Perhaps there should be some secret sauce to round out the dish, some really innovative taste to the meat, or maybe even some vegetables to round out the disporportionate amount of noodles to the small amount of meat.

At $9.00, that is equivalent to two jr. hamburgers from Five Guys; maybe a small pizza; or two super burritos. You could prob go to the Asian store, buy a pack of noodles for a coupla dollars!

Not worth the money, and disappointing - which most of the food trucks around here seem to be.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
Tried their garlic noodles with lemongrass chicken at Edgewood Eats.

Service was relatively quick, but that was to be expected as there really was no line.

Paid $10 for the garlic noodles with chicken - $7.50 for the noodles and $2.50 for the chicken.  I felt that the chicken portion was very small given the price.  Also, it seemed to be heavy on the ginger, which was not pleasant.  I would probably not get this again.

The garlic noodles were good.  They were probably a victim of so much hype, that by the time I tried them, though, they probably never could live up to expectations.  I did get a competitor's garlic noodles and think I preferred those.  An's noodles were by no means bad though.  They were milder in flavor as compared with the competitor, in my opinion.  An's were garlicky and buttery...good flavor, but the texture of the noodle was too limp for my taste.

Maybe I will have to go Thanh Long/Crustacean's and try the noodles at the restaurant.  This wasn't bad, but I won't go out of my way to have them again.
author: Brent T.

description:
If I'm craving for some really good homemade garlic noodles, this is the place to go. It's also pretty much the only reason why I'd go to this truck. Thanh Long (the less formal location) and Crustacean (dress-code required) are their brick and mortar restaurants and if you've been to either, the truck is a bargain (plus the service at their locations aren't the best).

You could get the garlic noodles on their own, or you can order the Combo Special where you get their famous garlic noodles and one of the following:
Lemongrass Beef Skewer
Lemongrass Chicken Skewer
Spice Pork Skewer
Yuzu Shrimp Skewer
Vegetable Stir-fry

What I typically order is the Combo w/the Yuzu Shrimp. You only get one skewer (and they are pretty small as well) and for the amount of noodle you get, I'd recommend buying another skewer (I like getting the Lemongrass Chicken or another Yuzu Shrimp). Or sometimes I get something from another truck and eat it w/the noodles. It's been hit and miss w/the noodles though. Sometimes it's overly dry, sometimes there's not enough garlic flavor.

The Vietnamese Iced Coffee had too much ice, so if you're also thirsty I wouldn't  recommend getting it.
author: Kitty K.

description:
4 stars for Garlic noodles $7.50 = delicious
2 stars for Chicken skewer $2.50 which was dry and lacked flavor

Portion sizes for the noodles were decent for the price. 
Average = 3 stars
author: Vivian D.

description:
I actually rather enjoyed the garlic noodles here.  I loved that they were soft, and full of flavor.. Garlicy, buttery, oily... Everyone who tried them loved them.

Also really enjoyed the meat we got on the side.  We got the chicken and the 5-spice pork.  Neither of them were super amazing, and it was very little meat, but at $2.50 I wasn't expecting much.  

The only kind of bummer here is that the garlic noddles, especially for $7.50, aren't necessarily a meal in itself.  I'm not one to dicker over a dollar or two, but still..

Either way, will definitely enjoy the noddles next time I come by this truck again.
author: Robert K.

description:
Garlic noodles at Thanh Long still the best ever, but garlic noodles from An The Go are less buttery and not as good.

But, if you still insist on waiting in the ridiculously long line for the noodles, which I did, I suggest you order garlic noodles and at least one skewer, so you get double the amount of noodles.  If you order only garlic noodles, you get a smaller container and less noodles.
author: Christina L.

description:
My stomach was growling hours before I even got to the SubZERO festival and An The Go's garlic noodles sounded delicious! After a quick look around, their noodles sounded most appetizing to me so I got in line. I ordered their signature noodles + a beef skewer, and my friend got another order of noodles + a lemongrass chicken skewer to share. 

Upon first glance... they didn't look so hot, both in temperature and ability to induce my appetite. Honestly, they looked like soggy spaghetti noodles with a tiny bit of sauce! :( We dug in, and hey, they were actually pretty good! My friend really liked hers, I think she said it was addicting. As for me, they were alright. I'm surprised to find out that their noodles are famous or something, I could hardly taste the garlic flavor (tasted more like butter!) and there's no way I'd pay $7.50 for this again. 

Their BEEF SKEWERS on the other hand were DELICIOUS. My beef skewer had four pieces on it, whereas there were only three pieces on the chicken one! The beef was super tender and I don't really remember how it was seasoned, it was just good! The chicken was dry though, and I didn't taste any of the lemongrass. 

Are they worth following? I'd grab a beef skewer if I saw them at another truck gathering, but otherwise I doubt I'll see them again. :(
author: Christine L.

description: Stopped by An The Go at an Off the Grid event in the Haight. I ordered the Garlic noodles with vegetables. It was so much food I literally had it for 3 separate meals. It was pretty good, not the best food truck I've been to, but decent. The garlic noodles lived up to their name. The vegetables could have been steamed a little bit longer though...they were a bit undercooked for my taste.
author: Stephanie T.

description: Ordered the  $9 Original Combo, I had heard from friends that this is the beast deal because it nearly the same amount of food as the $14 combo plate. Selected the Yuzu Shrimp, which was a nice plate, it was garlicky and the shrimp were not overcooked but to be honest it was a bit ordinary. The garlic did not have a lot of punch or bite. Noodles were plentiful and not overcooked but I really didn't get a lot of flavor from them (yes America, noodles are not supposed to be bland). It was an acceptable but not exciting dish. There were no flavors that got my attention or made me want more. I could survive on it but was rather unimpressed at this price point. My home made garlic sauce has far more fresh flavor, punch and layers of others tastes to entertain your tongue.
author: Bob L.

description:
Two words. Weak sauce. 

I was excited to try their garlic noodles because of their reputation, but I was seriously disappointed. They're dry and boring. It resembled something a novice home cook or 7-year-old would have made. I've made better garlic noodles at home. Anyone who thinks these garlic noodles are acceptable for consumption hasn't had good garlic noodles before. I'd rather choke down sandpaper. Thank you.

If you want delicious garlic noodles, try the noodles from the guy at Oakland Art Murmur. You know, THAT guy.

Oh, and bring some breath mints for later.
author: Anastasia B.

description:
I found this truck at Off the Grid in Palo Alto. When I saw the giant sign advertising garlic noodles, I had to try them out. I love garlic. I love noodles. Unfortunately, I was pretty disappointed with this place.

-Garlic noodles: Very plain. It's literally a mountain of noodles with some pieces of minced garlic thrown in. There were no other veggies or anything. There didn't even seem to be any other seasoning. The resulting noodles were dry and bland.

-5 Spice Pork: This was actually the only redeeming thing about this meal. The pork was really juicy and delicious. It wasn't spicy, which I was expecting based on the name, but it wasn't a big deal to me. 

-Yuzu Shrimp: Just like the garlic noodles, these were very plain. Definitely not worth paying for when I could just go out and buy a bag of frozen shrimp to get the same flavor.

-Dungeness Crab Puffs: Unlike other reviewers, I didn't think these were that bad. Then again, I had just eaten a big handful of plain, dry noodles beforehand. Even though the flavors were tasty enough to me, it was definitely overpriced.

Overall, the food was definitely not worth the price. And even if it were cheaper, I would not come back unless they totally revamped their "signature" garlic noodles.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
At the Moveable Feast in San Jose, I had already tried a couple of the food trucks so decided to give An the Go a whirl. Garlic and noodles just sounded amazing. All food trucks for the most part are not great when it comes to the price however, An the Go really did give a whole lot of carbs. Their garlic noodles to me were not amazing. I wished they were not as dry and it was almost as if they were filled with too much parmesan cheese like texture. I did enjoy the lemongrass beef skewer that came with the meal.I also ordered a side of eggrolls which was delicious yet super greasy. 

I would say its one of the best values (in terms of amount of food) at Moveable Feast if you are looking to get full, but after a while, the garlic noodles just aren't interesting in terms of taste.
author: Tracy Joy K.

description:
This is what i call " ONO- LISHES"!!!  Garlic Noodles... 5 Spice Pork, Chicken or Shrimp.. no matter what you select, it's all good.  The best food truck ever!  Need to bring my empty bucket next time for re-fills!!  Thank you for the South City / Gateway Blvd trucks!   San Mateo every Tuesday's!! 
Much Mahalo's to the Un The Go Staff!!
author: Cheryl S.

description: Visited the Off the Grid truck for some garlic noodles and Yuzu shrimp. Plenty of noodles with generous amounts of sprinkled garlic and four (4) ! pieces of shrimp on a skewer... about $10. Very spendy for what you get and definitely not justified by the culinary experience... no repeat business from me.
author: Judith T.

description:
I was just about to leave the "Movable Feast" at the San Jose subZERO festival, stuffed with every kind of taco and burrito imaginable. Then, I noticed one of my friends standing in line for An The Go:
"C'mon bro, let's go, we're all stuffed."
"No dude, I need to have their garlic noodles. I love that shit."
"Alright I guess we could try it out."

One of the best decisions of the night! Their garlic noodles look so simple in the box, but taste like melted butter garlic heaven when you bite into them. I've never tasted so much flavor packed into any bowl (or to-go carton) of noodles before. The texture is just how I liked it: very soft to the point where it melts in your mouth. Kind of reminded me of German spatzle, but in a vermicelli form.
author: Dmitriy S.

description:
Whoa?! 
People people lets calm down and reevaluate the situation!
How are so many people dissatisfied with the prices and portions? 
I for one, take a huge stand for An The Go not only because, hello? They make the best garlic noodles around but also because they work at festivals, freakin' events and I don't know, other cool places I suppose but the point is what festival or event have any of you gone to with the majority of the bay area's most popular food trucks and have gotten a meal drastically below 9 freakin' dollars? 
Cheepos. 
And why doesn't anyone know that the noodles are the main dish?? 
The meat is the side. As it should be. 
Geesh, spare a cow or two.
author: Toya R.

description:
This is another one of those - "I want to like you but you keep disappointing me" kind of relationships. Honestly, as I write this review, even though it's been a few weeks, I am still choking on garlic breath! 

Aside from the fact that they give you no indication of what you actually get when you order - a tiny little skewer and a massive amount of stinky, mushy noodles - you think you are getting a ton of food because, A.) they charge you a ton, B.) the containers are big and heavy - like their noodles. 

Honestly, if I'm paying $9 for a special, I want it to be...special! I don't want $8.50 of noodles and $.50 of meat - what's so special about that. Not to mention I can go to Safeway and get a 4 pack of Ramen noodles for $1, go home, over cook them, sprinkle them with garlic powder and get the same effect!

An The Go - please change your menu and your prices. Kthanxbye.
author: Karen K.

description:
This food truck is by no means a reflection off of Crustaceans or Thanh Long. It's kinda the generic version of those restaurants. Cheaper, faster, not as good. 

If you get the garlic noodles, you get a lot of noodles... and some garlic. It's so not worth it. I rather take the time to go and get the garlic noodles at Thanh Long. It's 1000x better. 

You get an add on of some kinda of protein for like $2.50. You need to move that decimal and make it 25 cents. It's not worth the $2.50 at all. It looks almost a little sad. A teeeeeeeeeeny portion of protein on top of a pretty generous portion of sub-par garlic noodles. No thank you. 

I shared this with my friend along with an order of Senor Sisig when they were at SF Truck Stop... and it was a hands down no contest. The flavors almost felt like they were non-existent in the garlic noodles. I'm almost a little upset I didn't get that fiery garlic breath you get after you get a REAL plate of garlic noodles!!!
author: Jeannie L.

description:
I should've read fellow Yelp reviews before having this for lunch today.  $9 for their "Special" combo:  Garlic Noodles and choice of meat.  I got the Spicy pork and was given about a two-serving mound of garlic noodles with a 5 inch skewer that even a 4th grader would be bickering about.  

$9.  Over-priced.
Garlic noodles.  Too much.
Meat.  Too less.

I would not get this again and would tell others at any Off the Grid event this is way over-priced and not worth it.
author: Kevin H.

description:
I love An's noodles and have been a fan for over ten years, but they simply don't translate on thier mobile truck.  The we're simply HORRIBLE! Mushy, luke warm, and under seasoned. I waited in line for 15 minutes (to be expected at MoFo in Sac) but to wait for mediocre food was unacceptable.  And to add insult to injury the big sweaty cook from the back was rude and lacked customer service skills. TIP: keep that guy in the back!

It was fun to fantasize about not needing to travel all the way to SF to get An's famous noodles, but a las that is not to be.   It was a waste of $7.50. I'd rather pay $30 more in gas and bridge tolls to get the real deal!
author: Anika C.

description:
Recently attended Off the Grid again in Larkspur. My usual go-to wasn't posted up this time, so I decided to find out what all the fuss was about with these garlic noodles. 

I got to the truck very late in the day, and was able to get my grubby little paws on the last order of garlic noodles (with beef skewer). Both the noodles (oodles of 'em) and the lemongrass beef skewer were very tasty. If you are a carb fiend, you will love. Even though I got the last of the batch, the noodles were still very moist and garlicky. The skewer was excellant. I would order this again and share a plate of noodles with someone... anyone - they really do give you a lot of noodles. 

The service was VERY friendly... extra star!
author: Kara B.

description:
Just went to it at the Moveable Feast in South San Jose.   I had the Combo noodle and chicken skewer.  Chicken skewer was good.   Noodles not so.  Dry noodles that only had a garlic cheesy powder on it.  Nothing else in the noodles.  Not what I expected. 

Order and Take out window was the same window so that kind of slowed down the process a bit.
author: Don C.

description:
I feel bad for all the poor reviews. I see a pattern of less protein, too much noodles, and it being overpriced. How 'bout some kudos for their garlic noodles?

I'm a noodle person so I may be a bit bias, but I think their noodles are comparable to PPQ and Thanh Long. I don't have to make reservations at a fancy restaurant, order wine, order crab - I can just go to An The Go and get their noodles. Okay, so they're a bit pricey, but if you think about it, you spend about $7-$10 (on avg) on food trucks anyway, so $9 for a bunch of awesome noodles and some meat isn't that bad. I agree they can put in a bit more meat on their skewers, but I honestly think the ratio between noodles and meat is so off, that it makes it seem like there's not enough meat. I think they should give us less noodles and charge $7.50 for noodles and skewers.
author: Rosie W.

description:
Garlic noodles, garlic noodles, garlic noodles - I love me some garlic noodles. You get a HUGE portion of garlic noodles in your order and true, the skewer of meat is not plentiful considering how much you need to go around for your abundance of garlic noodles but hey, I can eat the garlic noodles on their own. Makes for great leftovers b/c I certainly can't eat it all in one sitting. 

I tried the Spice Pork (not spicy pork) and it was a good complement to the noodles. Slightly salty for my taste but overall, one of those great meals that hit the spot when you just want to indulge in a mouth full of flavor.
author: Isabelle L.

description: I had the garlic noodles & lemongrass chicken skewer when they made an appearance at the Moveable Feast. The noodles were ok. The chicken skewer was pretty good, tender & juicy. I'd probably skip the noodles next time & just opt for the skewer :P
author: Annie M.

description:
I like noodles. I really like noodles and these garlic noodles are yummy but you get a TON of noodles and a tiny skewer of meat. The meat is delicious though and thats why you want more of it. I've had all the meat and it's all good. I kinda wish the meat wasn't as tasty because then we wouldn't care that we are getting short changed on the meat portion of the meal and paying $9 for some noodles we could probably make at home if we really tried.

But with all that said, when I see An the Go park on a street I get excited, like I said, I like noodles.
author: jen b.

description:
Not the best food truck.

They didn't have much choice- garlic noodles, salad, skewers, spring rolls.
I got the combo with garlic noodles because I knew I was going to be hungry if I didn't.  $9 it came with one skewer and was quote my co-worker "80% noodles, 10% meat, 10% garlic" Not the best choice for a work lunch.

The best part was that they came and parked in my parking lot. Yay for laziness.

As for the food. It was meh, probably worth $4.

If they came again, I'd probably walk to Mollie Stones.
author: Skye W.

description:
Since I decided to go to Off the Grid yesterday, all I had heard about for the last week was Garlic Noodles, Garlic Noodles, Garlic Noodles. 

I don't really know how to describe them except to say that they're good but not 9 dollars good. I'm not sure if it's the portion size or the fact that they're just not really THAT good. I think I would have liked it alot better if it was 6 or 7 dollars because I feel like I could get noodles that good for that price elsewhere. 

As for the noodles themselves, the best description I can really think of is that there is no obvious garlic taste. I can't quite pinpoint what the taste is except that there is probably soy sauce in it. The pork that we ordered with it was very flavorful and good barbeque. But you only get one skewer and it's kind of like really, that's it?

Service: Guy at the window was very nice and accommodating. There was a customer a couple people behind us who was a vegetarian. By the time she got up to the window, they had sold out of the spring rolls and the vegetable garlic noodles. I felt like the guy was very nice while dealing with her. As for the food wait, that was alot longer than anywhere else we had gone.

Overall, this is a good fallback if I can't find any other trucks that interest me, but otherwise, I'd aim for other options.
author: Karen C.

description:
Another Food Truck Night at my local Willows Market in Menlo Park. This Monday evening there were 5 trucks to choose from and I decided to give An The Go a try. The menu was basically Garlic Noodles with your choice of a half dozen different meat/veggie skewers for $9. I choose the Garlic Noodles with a Lemongrass Chicken Skewer.

The portion of noodles was quite large but the chicken skewer was smaller than I expected. The noodles were good not great. They were really lacking in garlic and had an excessive amount of Parmesan cheese which made the noodles dry. The Lemongrass Chicken was BBQ chicken pieces on a skewer. Nothing more nothing less. 

Overall the meal was just adequate. It filled me up but for $9 I was expecting something really yummy. Unless they come up with something new and special I won't be eating at An The Go again.
author: Craig H.

description: Barely adequate. Greasy limp noodles with odd taste. Crab puffs were decent. Kind of like the Pick Up Stix wontons.
author: Michael G.

description:
Nice guys but I was less then impressed by the food. I believe it's an Over / Under problem with a lack of balance:

1) Over-priced
2) Over-noodled
3) Over-salty
4) Under skewered (not enough meat)

I understand noodles are cheap and meat is expensive but the amount of noodles I got dwarved my little stick-o-meat.
author: L C.

description: Agree with fellow yelper L C. The smell of the garlic noodles is what compelled me to try this place as we were visiting the giftcenter/jewelry mart on a Saturday morning. 3 of us ordered 2 garlic noodle combos, one with beef, one with pork. The flavor of everything was pretty good, but for $9 something per combo, there was very little meat. 1 small skewer each and lots of spaghetti garlic noodles. The 3 of us couldn't finish the noodles, but the lack of meat left something to be desired.
author: Veronica C.

description:
Tasty garlic noodles.. very garlicky. Just a tiny bit too soft to my liking. Must eat it while it's warm otherwise it's kinda icky.

As people noted, you get a lot of noodles with a choice of topping that is way too little. I got a single skewer of beef which was gone in 5 bites, leaving like two third of the noodles left hanging without topping... Should give less noodles and more topping.
author: Agustinus T.

description:
Is the food hot?

Well, if you mean, "is it a HOT MESS," I say absolutely!  

Now, there are a lot of overrated food trucks out there these days, but An the Go has got to take the prize for most ridiculously overrated.  When I tried it at a Moveable Feast event, this was the truck with the longest line (and slowest service).  Got to be good, right?  No, that's really not the way to judge a place.  

For about $8, we got a box filled with noodles. Filled with lots of noodles.  Filled with lots of seriously overcooked, overly garlicky, sadly disappointing noodles.  Anybody could do this at home.  I mean, it's easy to not develop interesting flavors.  It's even easier to boil the noodles until they're not worth eating anymore-- so I'm hardly impressed that An the Go manages to do both, and then has the nerve to not only SERVE them, but to also charge 8 bucks for the dubious honor.  

Not worth the space in the stomach--this got left behind in the trash.
author: John W.

description: Had this at the Off the Grid in El Cerrito/Albany.  Got noodles and shrimp skewers. Shrimp were tasty...3 stars. Garlic noodles were overcooked, mushy, not garlic-y enough. Only had about 6 bites and threw the rest away...1 star.
author: Jennifer P.

description: Absolutely delicious, love , love love the garlic noodles, cooked to perfection and full of flavor. I didn't have to look at any other options once I saw the truck was there. The price was good for a combination with one skewer $9. Friendly service made our visit to this truck delightful. Would definitely recommend.
author: Pearl B.

description:
Wow, the An family must be making major bank if they can get away with charging $7.50 + $2.50 for plain garlic noodles and a barely-there meat skewer. Hm.. I think I want to marry into the An family...

I was so ecstatic that food trucks FINALLY came to West San Jose (MVBL Feast at Garden City Casino at Saratoga & Stevens Creek). WSJ doesn't get ANY love! But I'll save that gripe for another day. I had actually done a bit of Yelp research before going and I should've placed more weight on the negative reviews I read for An The Go. 

I ordered the garlic noodles + lemongrass chicken skewer and a Vietnamese iced coffee (total = $13, ouch). Now, I'm a legit garlic addict, so I can't say I didn't appreciate the uber-garlicky-ness of the noodles. But they had NOTHING else going for them. The skewer is presumably supposed to add some dimension to the plainness of the noodles, and it might have if it wasn't so tiny and mediocre. Their Viet iced coffee also didn't taste Vietnamese at all. Tasted like a generic iced latte drink from a generic coffee shop.

An the Go gets one star from me for making food that doesn't taste like crap. There's that, at least...
author: Vicky C.

description:
I have a little beef w/ An the Go. And when I say "little beef" I mean there is very little meat on the skewers. I would guess maybe 2-3oz of meat. I get it - they're only $4. But I still expect more.

The noodles, on the other hand, resemble a small mountain. A small delicious mountain of intertwined garlicky goodness. And as much as I love them, I would suggest they reduce the garlic noodle portions and increase the meat portions. 

Don't get me wrong - I LOVE garlic noodles. I would marry them and have babies with them if I could. We would live in the suburbs and have two pomeranians. But a ginormous pile of noodles is not enough to make a meal. I needz me some meat. So I'd trade half the noodle portion for a few extra pieces of chicken or beef.

With that being said, An the Go has the most buttery, galicky noodles ever. They are my faves. Too bad I can only eat them on cheat days.

3.5 stars
author: Mariela D.

description:
$7.50 for Garlic noodles?? no meat, no nothing on the side? really???   Yelpers don't give into the hype!  Just because they are mobile and exotic doesn't mean that they get to rip us off.. there used to be a day where mobile trucks gave us a bargain because of the low overhead...

Anyways, on to the review.

so, I refused to pay $7.50 for PLAIN Garlic Noodles...  So instead I tasted a friends dish and here's my review on that:

Taste: Good, but nothing to call themselves "Famous" for.
The noodles? something I can make myself at home... here is my version:  Take some al dente spaghetti noodles; saute some garlic in clarified brown butter and olive oil;  combine it all together with with garlic salt and Parmesan cheese until it's well incorporated... voila! Garlic Noodles! and all for less than $2.00 when made at home.

Additionally,  I ordered a crispy spring roll, and what I got was an anemic and tasteless/half fried small "crispy egg roll" $2.50 

Vietnamese coffee.  The coffee was good and strong made with condensed milk so it was sweet $3.
author: amy m.

description: I was walking by Chameleon cafe in Nob Hill and was pleasantly surprised by the An The Go food truck. Their Garlic noodles are AWESOME. It was $9 for noodles and pork so a little on the high side but it's tasty and quick. Thanks for the food! Looking forward to having garlic noodles again.
author: Carlos A.

description: Bland and expensive. Was looking forward to the food but was disappointed with extra dry noodles and cold scewers. Dayum mayne it wasnt a good day for my wallet and taste budz bro
author: Tha U.

description:
i've been to this food truck several times, mainly for their garlic noodles.  they really get around the bay area as i've seen them in sf, the peninsula and south bay at various food truck festivals and gatherings.

i ordered an's famous garlic noodles with lemongrass chicken skewer ($9).  the noodles were delicious, with a good blend of garlic and oil.  i really like the finely minced garlic on the noodles, as opposed to pieces of garlic, which might be overpowering in one bite.  i do wish the noodles were hot when my ordered was called.  i sat down to eat almost immediately after picking up my order and felt the noodles were lukewarm at best, and nearing cold by the time i was at the bottom of the heap of noodles.

unfortunately, the meat was quite disappointing.  almost half of the chicken was burnt, which didn't make me feel good about eating it.  although most of it was tender and seasoned with a good amount of lemongrass.  i do wish that they gave me more than just one skewer of meat, but i guess that is the standard for the noodle dishes - lots of noodles, little bit 'o meat.

for $9, i did feel that i was given a decent serving of food for lunch, and it was certainly very filling.  i'll probably be back, and perhaps next time, i'll request that they not overgrill the chicken.
author: Ellen L.

description:
The one craving I frequently regret indulging is fried food. It's never as good in my mouth as it is in my mind & An The Go is just another example of this vicious cycle. 

At OTG Civic Center, I ordered coconut shrimp ($5 for 3) & Vietnamese spring rolls ($2 for 2, cut into halves.) The shrimp were nicely fried on the outside with an ample sprinkling of coconut but the batter inside was thick & doughy. I did like the tart & spicy vinegar sauce. The wrapping on the spring rolls were chewy; I was looking forward to that satisfying crunch, but no. Again, the less-sticky-than-usual sweet & sour sauce was the best part of that dish. 

As much as I enjoy a good dipping sauce, it should compliment, not overshadow the main event. Two stars for their mediocre fried selections.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
I was really disappointed by the food definitely wouldn't eat here again.  
The garlic noodles are uninspired (tastes like noodles sauteed with garlic salt) and overpriced, considering there's no meat and no vegetables.  The skewers are ok, but can't stand up to the plethora of amazing offerings from other food trucks. The coconut shrimp (3 pieces for $5) isn't anything to write home about and I really expect more for $5 at a food truck.  Won't be eating here again.
author: Susanne H.

description:
Thanh Long has the best garlic noodles in the city in my opinion, so when I learned about An The Go and it happened to be at today's OTG: 5M, I knew exactly what I was going to have for lunch. But I'm very sorry to report that I was seriously disappointed by the price and the portion. 

The portion of garlic noodles they give you is great, I'm not complaining about that, but $7.50 is a pretty steep price tag for just noodles. Also, I went with the stir fried veggies on top and for $2.50 all I got was 3 pieces of broccoli, a bunch of celery, a few onions and a few pieces of carrot. SERIOUSLY? For $2.50? That should be a crime. I rounded out my meal with a viet iced coffee. 

Grand total for lunch today? $13. 

#totallynotworthit
author: Jen D.

description:
This truck is operated by the An family of restaurants (Thanh Long and Crustacean)

If you're gonna get the garlic noodles (and why wouldn't you??), make sure you partake in one of their skewers. Delicious, however, by itself, it gets a little tiring. In retrospect, it would make more sense for An The Go to offer them together as a combo and not as an ala carte option.  

I have some qualms with the pricing of $7.50 for garlic noodles, even if they are generous and pack it in. As griped, the skewers are necessary accompaniments to enhance the experience, and though at only $2.50... $10.00 for a meal off a truck???
author: Aileen A.

description:
An The Go is a way to experience Thanh Long's very popular garlic noodles without trekking to Outer Sunset.

I've been to Thanh Long once and neglected to order the noodles (I know, shame), so it's nice to see An The Go taking Thanh Long's prized dish to the streets.

It's worth having this carb-fest of a meal if you have an active lifestyle or plan to share.  

Let me take that back, it's worth trying it regardless.

I initially had a puzzled reaction upon seeing what I've been hearing about for years.  But once I tried it, I finally understood why.
author: JC R.

description:
A huge portion of tasty garlic noodles.  Great tasting skewers.  The crew were super duper courteous and friendly.  That first impression at the order window really does play.
Could it use some sriracha?  Couldn't EVERYTHING use some sriracha?  Really, they were great.
author: Roni L.

description:
I like their Garlic Noodles, Crab Puff, & Vietnamese Ice Coffee. 
I like An The Go when I'm On The Go.
author: Mariel F.

description:
Crustacean on wheels? Heck yes!! I love how they come out to my neck of the woods so I don't have to make the drive into the city all the time. They always have a long line of people waiting to put their order in. Most of the time I'll order food for lunch but other times I'll order it and save it for dinner for my husband and I =)

Their garlic noodles are amazing. I'll bring them back to my office and my colleagues are dying to have a taste. The smell is super strong and if you're a garlic lover, it's like music to your ears. 

I've gotten the garlic noodles with their beef skewers before and the skewers were okay. I usually just get the garlic noodles by it self and add my own veggies to it.

Yes it is a bit on the greasy side but who cares? I love garlic and noodles and these noodles are oozing with garlic flavor.
author: Betty D.

description:
The food truck came by on Tuesday last week into Palo Alto Sq, the day when a few food trucks gather in a corner of the parking lot.  There was an ice cream truck, a chicken-focused  truck, and a Peruvian truck.

I opted for An The Go and--in general--I was not disappointed.  While my friends look like they barely got filled on the chicken truck (piddly portions), An the Go provided heaping amount of garlic noodles in their $9 set.  It is VERY Good (and heavy with butter? because I was not hungry even at 7pm at night...and kept belching from all the fullness of the noodles).

I got the special which is $9 set with one skewer and garlic noodles.  For an extra $2.50, you can get another skewer.  

My set was the lemongrass beef and noodles.  The beef was not too flavorful and looked pretty lonely in the sea of wavy noodles.  Luckily I had opted to add a shrimp skewer so it was less lonely.  The shrimp skewer is VERY flavorful--I wished I had taken two of that instead of the beef.

My coworkers--being vegetarian--got the noodles with veggies. Now that's a pretty good deal.  There were ample veggies in their set, although I still prefer having some animal protein.

Overall the garlic noodles taste as-if you were at Crustacean (I guess they are affiliated since it's on their food truck).  YUM!

Next time,I'll make sure to get my veggies with the set, plus my shrimp skewer.
author: Sonny W.

description:
$9 for a skewer of pork and a pile of "garlic" noodles.  

I've been wanting to try this truck, since I haven't been able to try Thanh Long.  I was disappointed.  Both the pork and noodles were salty ... very salty.  The garlic noodles seemed to be missing the main ingredient.  

I'm not sure how good the noodles are at Crustacean or Thanh Long, but if I want garlic noodles, I'll make them at home for a fraction of the cost.  AND with lots of garlic!
author: Michael M.

description:
The line for An the Go's wares was hilaribad (yes, hilaribad) at San Mateo's Moveable Feast so I was glad I got the chance to try them out without much fuss this past weekend at SJ Eats.

The noodles are $7.50 for a large helping; I got the yuzu shrimp skewer with my noodles for an extra $2.50 and received three medium-sized shrimp. They were cooked well and the sauce was yummy, but I didn't really taste any yuzu in the sauce, just a savory soy flavor.

I'm seeing a lot of comments about mushy noodles, greasy noodles, and dry noodles, but I actually really enjoyed mine. I don't expect Asian wheat noodles to be as "al dente" as Italian-style hard wheat/semolina pastas or egg noodles (though they should still have a bit of resistance), and one of my favorite preparations for noodles at home is close to what An the Go does: plain, dry, and dressed with lots of oil and minced garlic. It's not fancy, but when done right it's pretty satisfying.

However, the fact that I do noodles like this at home is also why my rating is not going any higher than three stars: for $7.50 An the Go gives you roughly a third of a pound of cooked noodles dressed with plain oil and minced garlic, and nothing else. It's good, but as an avid noodle eater (hush!) I know that I could boil up a full pound of imported, air-dried whole-grain Italian spelt noodles in water seasoned with unrefined, sun-dried sea salt and dress them with local, unfiltered extra virgin olive oil and local organic garlic and STILL not spend $7.50. I very much enjoyed my meal of plain, dry noodles and three shrimp; I just don't think it was a ten-dollar meal, is all.
author: James L.

description:
Stopped by here and ordered the combo with the garlic noodles and lemongrass chicken skewer, as recommended by other reviewers. 

Honestly, the concept of this truck isn't all that amazing. The food is alright, definitely something you could easily make at home. However, for a food truck, they do hook it up with hella noodles though. It was enough for me and my bf to share. The noodles are very moist and super garlicky. Your breath will stink so bad after but whatever!
author: Malyssa C.

description: I ran into this truck at the Treasure Island Flea Market.  I hadn't had breakfast, and most of the other food stands were offering super sweet items, such as donuts, or items heavy on the meat.  When I walked past this truck and saw both garlic noodles and Vietnamese Iced coffee, I was sold.  Wow, I had not idea what an amazing choice I had made.  The garlic noodles were the perfect consistency and had just the right amount of garlic.  Though really can you ever have too much garlic?  The iced coffee was yummy and the service was fantastic!   After arriving home I immediately found them on facebook so I could stalk their location.  I am looking forward to my net meal from here.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
This place works a lot better in theory than in reality.

I had the garlic noodles with lemongrass beef skewer, while attending Off the Grid @ Fort Mason. As many of the other yelpers write, $9 for one skewer of meat and a heap of soggy noodles is... to me... definitely over-priced. The beef itself was alright, but really nothing special. And the noodles were really disappointing :( They were soggy, cold, and the texture was too greasy and powdery for me. It felt like they just piled on a punch of garlic powder, and had no actual pieces of garlic in there for the whole authentic "garlic" flavoring. 

If you want garlic noodles, go with Sunflower or Perilla. While it wasn't a terrible, I won't be going back to An the Go as I can definitely find better somewhere else.
author: Lucinda W.

description: One of my favorite food trucks. The portions are very generous and I don't feel they are over priced as others have said. I've only had the pork and veggie but I look forward to trying some of the other options. The staff has always been very friendly with me.
author: Jesse P.

description: Mediocre garlic noodles. I think I like the ones at Perilla better.
author: Food E.

description:
Hmm, I don't know about this one. I was so excited to find out about the  An The Go food truck. They were at the OTG McCoppin hub on a Saturday.I am obsessed with garlic noodles. Even though they were running late to get there and we were in a time crunch,but I didn't care, I was so eager to to try the garlic noodles. 
The noodles cost $7.50, ok portioned, on the smaller side. Since it's from a truck, it was obviously pre-prepared. I am not sure how long they pre prepared it, when I opened the container, it was luke warm and the noodles were soggy and sticking together. When I took a bite, my face went sour because the garlic noodles tasted more salty than garlicky. Like eating play doh. I also had the coconut shrimp, tasted good, but not worth the price of $5 for 3 shrimps.
author: Valerie P.

description:
Tried the famous Garlic Noodles for the first time at Off the Grid. The line was long, so I knew it must be good. I got the noodles with vegetables for $9. The noodles were great, and the veggies were cooked just right. The only thing I wish was that there was more vegetables, because after a few bites I was left with a box full of garlic noodles.

Tried them again at The Truck Stop and got the lemongrass chicken. The chicken was cooked well, very tender, and went great with the noodles.

Definitely will have them again, but am going to have to brush my teeth at least three times after eating it.
author: Sarah H.

description:
Evidently the $7.50 noodle deal is dead.  At Off the Grid Hayes Valley, your only option was $9 for noodles and single skewer.  Honestly, I would have been fine with just the noodles, so it's a shame they don't offer the noodles alone.

That said, the garlic noodles are pretty good with a reasonable balance of garlic-ness and actual noodle flavor.  In fact, I'd be ok with them being even more garlicky if it didn't make me sweat garlic the next day.  My noodles were a bit greasier than I would have liked (soaked through the paper takeout box...) and were a bit doughy in places.  The noodles alone should really be a $5 item.

The skewer was nothing special -- it's just grilled meat.  Unless you over/under cook it, you can't really do it wrong.
author: Andrew C.

description:
I'm a regular at Moveable Feast Southside (mvbl.org) and this place consistently has no line....unfortunately, now I see why.  

$9 for a combo with garlic noodles and meat of your choice (there are also vegetarian options like tofu).  

Had the lemongrass beef.  Flavor was good but nothing special.  Included one (count 'em, ONE) skewer with 4 pieces of beef (moderately sized).  For $9, I expected two skewers of meat at least.  

The beef was sitting atop a seemingly bottomless pile of garlic noodles.  Frankly, they taste like noodles covered in the garlic butter used to make garlic bread.  Yech!
author: Katrina V.

description: If you can't make it to crustacean or thang long than this is the place. Nothing fancy but still the same garlic noodles
author: Ryan C.

description:
I dont know what to say about An The Go. I guess I expected a lot from this truck since I know this is An Family from Crustacean and Thanh Long. 

First off $7.50 for noodles ONLY...If i want meat on my noodles, i had to add extra $2.50. Maybe for the restaurant, this price is ok. But if youre competing with other food trucks, this wont cut it!

The noodles looks so pale and it was so oily like it was pre made and they just microwaved it before serving it to us. 

Sorry An The Go ... i like your restaurants ... but I dont think im coming back to your truck on Off the Grid Events ...
author: RED C.

description:
I haven't had the infamous An Family garlic noodles in awhile and was surprised to find their food truck last nite at Off the Grid. 
The noodle price is cheaper than what you'd pay for at their restaurants but it didn't taste as good, $7.50.   I had vegts with mine and nothing to write home about, $2.50.  

The next day, the noodles had more flavor as leftover.  Maybe it's better to just take it home and wait a day to eat it.  It seemed much more oiler the following day after the fat had time to settle to the bottom.
author: Ry T.

description: Last time they hit Edgewood eats I was totally denied. THe line was super long and by the time I got there sold out. Sonofabitchbastard. Well I tried again a second time, still long lines but I got through. Coconut shrimp and garlic noodles. The shrimp were good, nice and crisp though for $5 you only get three of them. The noodles, good flavor but overcooked so they were too soft. Sigh. I'm sure if I went at the beginning I could have gotten better examples but I just dont get out of work that early. I will give them another try as I want to see what the skewers are like too.
author: Kim N.

description:
Two word summary:
Uneven portions

Breakdown:
- $7.50 for a huge portion of garlic noodles. They're very good.
- Unless you like starch-only meals, you have to add $2.50 for a little skewer.
- Good Vietnamese iced coffee.

Takeaway:
I'd rather pay $5 for 2/3 the amount of noodles they give and $5 for two skewers to achieve a better balanced $10 lunch.
author: LM M.

description:
F'n awesome, if ya can't make it to SF they'll bring 'em to you.  I can't get me enough of them garlic noodles.  The only reason people aren't giving them 5 stars is because they'r a bunch of cheap ass mother f***ers making up excuse after excuse as to why they aren't the shit, when they know they are the real deal.

An's recipe as to die for people!!!  That's the reason no matter where they go they always have the longest lines wait'n to get their grubby little paws all over them.  $9 bucks isn't gonna break the bank and if it does, theres plenty of other cheap ass roach coach food trucks you can go hit up.
author: Sean B.

description: Actually quite good. Try the garlic noodles with the chicken and lemon grass beef skewers. Quite nice and fast service.
author: Rick H.

description:
Stopped by at Sactomofo 4, since ive heard all about their garlic noodles.

Got the garlic noodles and chicken skewer.  chicken was good, noodles are good, noodles are more italian garlic flavor than asian.  So if your expecting asian flavors you might be dissappointed.  as it was the noodles were pretty great, but i did wish there was a little bit more intense garlic flavor.  even so the wife was avoiding me for two days due to garlic pores.
author: Chris K.

description: As noted by everyone else, the noodles are simply amazing! And at $7.50, cheaper than if you were to try them at Crustacean.  However, the grilled veggies (vegetarian alternative to the meat skewers they offer) are not worth the $2.50 price.  So go to Off the Grid (Civic Center) and try the An noodles, and wait about 15 minutes for the food coma...
author: Gev M.

description: I liked it.  I  was focused on the noodles though and it didn't disappoint me at all.   $7.50 for noodles that are tasty.   It was OFF the grid so I got my meat somewhere else. ;)  Got to try the others too.  But for what I was focused on the Garlic noodles.   I need to give them 4 stars.   I'm still going to crave for it.  And I'm still going to go here for it.   :)
author: Homer S.

description: My friends and I were at off the grid belmontand we ordered the combination noodle plate. I got the side of shrimp and my friend got the beef. For $9 we got a big pile of noodles with 4 small shrimp and my friend got less than 1.5 oz of beef (I ended up weighing on scale).  I know that the food cost on noodles is very low and was very disappointed to see hardly any protein, especially for the price. The noodles were ok, needed more flavor, garlic or onions or both and less oil. The texture was good.
author: Denise M.

description:
I really regret eating off of this truck tonight at Off The Grid-P. Hill. I had the noodles with beef skewer, and an order of crab puffs. $16.50 total. The price didn't bother me because I figured the food would be great. I was wrong. The noodles were bland and there were 4 small pieces of beef that were supposed to be a lemongrass marinade. The beef was cooked properly, but there was no flavor in the noodles or meat. The crab puffs on the other hand were fishy. They were so terrible that we ate 1/2 out of 4 and threw them away. 

I paid for spaghetti noodles that had no flavor, a tiny bit of flank steak and the WORST crab puffs of my life. 

With all of the other options, this truck needs to step up or get the cut from Off The Grid.
author: Kim S.

description:
Went to Edgewood Eats yesterday and Joanna S wanted us to give this a try...I had already bought the garlic noodles from Little Green Cyclo and we were going to compare to see which dish was going to win. After giving each dish a try, I'd definitely give it to An the Go for flavor. I'm not tooo sure about the texture though--noodles were a little bit too soft...but I like the taste so much...I can bear to ignore the texture! 
 
Well we can't have noodles without adding some meat to it right? ERRR (wrong)! I could have done without the Beef Kabob...for $2.50 and 4 pieces of meat that were forgettable? Not worth it. Maybe the Chicken skewers are better but by the time I got to ordering, they were sold out :T Maybe next time? Or maybe next time I'll just order the noodles...anyway at $7.50 this place was cheaper than Little Green Cyclo for their garlic noodles and tasted way better. 
 
This truck had the longest line out of all of the trucks at Edgewood Eats...if the line is super long again next time I check it out...I probably wouldn't bother waiting and just give another truck a shot.
author: Jessica H.

description: I tried their famous garlic noodles at Off the Grid at Fort Mason on Friday. First thought: Why do these food truck noodles cost $7.50? Cuz they weigh over a pound! I added a skewer of grilled shrimp for $1.50 for a total of $9 for the combo. It does seem a bit on the pricey end, but they do give you a lot of starchy, delicious noodles. I definitely had plenty to share, AND lots of leftovers. I plan to try the lemongrass chicken skewers next time too.
author: Leslie H.

description:
Totally agree with LM M.

An the Go needs to provide better portioned, balanced lunches.

Garlic noodles by itself costs $7.50. That's a lot for garlic noodles, but it's also a lot of noddles at slightly less than 1 lb. Add a skewer for $2.50, so your "lunch" of 1 lb of garlic noodles and 1 skewer of meat is $10. Sorry, but a 3-item combo from Panda Express costs less, has more vegetables, and tastes just as good.

I doubt An the Go will revamp the menu, so, if you plan to go here's my advice: Take 2 or more people who don't mind family style eating. Have one person order the garlic noodles and the rest the skewers. Then, go back to the office and eat family style. Trust me, there will be enough garlic noodles for everyone, and you'll feel you got a better deal.

Oh, and the garlic noodles are just OK. PPQ garlinc noodles are better. These were mushy and overcooked, which could have been because they were sitting around in the truck as opposed to being freshly made in the kitchen. So, maybe Crustacean has better garlic noodles than PPQ, but the truck executes it poorly.
author: rosanna c.

description:
One word to describe the garlic noodles, SPECTACULAR.  Many tried to imitate but can't even come close to it. 

I had 2 orders on the spot and bought 2 more to go. The beef skewer is delicious as well. Compliment the food with great hospitality and they get 5 stars from me. I will be back for more.
author: Porky T.

description: I'm not sure what other folks here were eating but my noodles were super garlicky, retained their flavor well, and were complimented by a tasty skewer of beef.  Despite the long lines, the food comes out fast, hot, and delicious.
author: Sara S.

description:
The garlic noodles are muy delicioso. Good amount for what you pay but...

...whats up with the dinky single skewer of protein? Maybe put less garlic noodles (but please don't) and an extra skewer? Like, the amount of meat you're eating (pause) is not proportional to the amount of noodles. -1

Slightly overpriced for what you get. -1

Three stars isn't bad, THIS PLACE IS YUMMY!
author: Harold C.

description:
I remember I gave 5 stars for Thanh Long.. my experience there was almost heavenly.. the food.. the attentive service.. AWESOMENESS!!!  

Last Saturday my last stop was An The Go.  I was there for lunch and came back for dinner specifically for An The Go.  I knew that if I LOVED the garlic noodles back then, my love for it shall remain after this consumption.  

The service was awesome in every way- even from the truck!  I mentioned the welcoming feeling and "Awww" moment I had w/ the guy that took my order and when he called my # out in my SJ Eats review.. I still cannot forget that!

Anyway.. they accept Visa/MC and that's always a plus.  I don't normally carry cash and it's a pain to stop by an ATM just to pull out cash for cash only establishments.  I was thrilled when I learned that they do accept it.

I ordered the garlic noodles w/ beef skewers.  Though I'm 100% Vietnamese, sometimes I swear I'm a white male as I really technically need just meat (and more meat) and potatoes.. I love chicken too (boiled, grilled, steamed, fried, broiled, baked, ground, rotisserie, etc.) but the choice that stood out to me was the beef skewers.  

The garlic noodles was yummy after 4 days in the fridge.. this isn't chow mein type of noodles so it did not get all starchy so that was a plus!  The beef was a little too well done for my taste but now I know better.. "Extra rare por favor."  

Would I come back to Thanh Long?  YES!!

Would I come back to An The Go?  YES!! 

I need to try Crustacean.. 

Either way.. awesome product.. awesome customer service.
author: Tram N.

description:
Some may call the garlic noodles boring... but when I order garlic noodles, garlic noodles is what I want.  The deliciousness of garlic and goodness of noodles is what I'm talking about.  Vegetables will only take up precious space in my take-out container.  Obviously, the garlic noodles from An The Go will not taste exactly the same as the ones from Thanh Long - remember, it's a completely different kitchen.
