People complain about the price but next time you feel like standing in the Chairman Bao line, head over to Chinatown first to see how much a pork bun really costs.  Let's admit it, we're all into this whole food truck craze because we're buying into the gimmick that gourmet food trucks serve some sort of amazing food that cannot be found elsewhere.  It's this elusive quality that draws us in.  That and it's like a party when you hit up OTG.  The trucks know that and that's how they get away with charging wayyyyyy more.  At least An The Go doesn't charge MORE than Thanh Long.  I can't say the same for some of those other trucks.
author: Peggy N.

description:
$9 for 4 clearly previously frozen shrimp with little to no flavor and 1000 calories worth of overcooked, mushy, lukewarm noodles flavored with garlic salt? Holy s@#, you must be F*****G KIDDING ME. I'm not even mad, I just don't know what to say.  It was one of those meals where I was actually more disappointed in myself for choosing it than mad at the restaurant. Threw it away immediately and got a sandwich.

How does this place exist?
author: Stephen R.

description: I had two lemongrass chicken skewers ($2.50).   I wasn't very impressed.  The chicken was fatty and tough and the flavor was a little overwhelming for me.  The portions are a little stingy for the price too.
author: A M.

description:
When I heard about this truck it sounded interesting and I wanted to give it a try. My end result was mixed.

I ordered the "famous" garlic noodles ($7.50) with the add-on of one 5 spice pork skewer ($2.50) and a crunchy Vietnamese spring roll ($2.50). The skewer was good; it was juicy and moist with a good amount of flavor. The spring roll was fresh and had a nice lightness from not being over fried. 

However, the garlic noodles were a huge let down; they were soggy and stuck together, and a bit too much oil. They had a good garlic flavor, but that's all it had, it was just plain with nothing to add a depth to the color or flavor. The addition of a bit of fresh shredded cabbage or some diced scallions really would've helped make this dish stand out more. As it was, not really worth the price.
author: Gary T.

description: U would think "mmmm garlic noodles, I have to get it!" This is the worst garlic noodles I've ever had. The garlic noodles were disgusting and the beef skewers were dry. Such a waste of money. We ended throwing it away. Not a fan.
author: Felicia S.

description: After eating at many local foodie spots (trucks and restaurants) in my area I have to include a review of the infamous garlic noodles.  An The Go makes good garlic noodles and the meat on a stick are flavorful but I am still left unsatisfied.  After trying both An The Go and the Little Green Cyclo... the battle of the bay garlic noodle champion is... the Little Green Cyclo.  Sorry An The Go.... your noodles are too soggy and do not have the same savory garlic flavor as other foodie spots in the bay.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Ended up grabbing some lunch from An the Go while it was stationed at the Treasure Island Flea Market. 

We ordered:
-Garlic noodles: Decent enough, but they really are just that: noodles + garlic + a bit of seasoning. They aren't that satisfying on their own so definitely add a skewer. I went to Thanh Lan a few years ago and remember the noodles being a lot tastier there.
-Shrimp spring salad: I loved the miso dressing but otherwise just a salad. 

Overall, I wouldn't seek this truck out but it'll do for lunch if it happens to be around.
author: Elizabeth M.

description: Yup, only tried the garlic noodles and found them too soft and overly garlicked, although I can't say they really tasted bad. Just too much starch overall. Not something I'd go for again.
author: Lisa K.

description: Went here during off the grid in El Cerrito and it is definitely my favorite food truck. The garlic noodles are perfect in consistency, taste, and serving size. I always get the shrimp and lemongrass chicken. Chicken is good, especially if you're a person who really enjoys chicken. Shrimp is better. Only complaint is the serving size of the meat. A little pricey, but that can be expected from a food truck. Definitely recommend it though.
author: Jasmine S.

description:
Went to Off the Grid last night and heard about their Garlic Noodles. So I tried it with the Yuzu shrimp skewer. Total came to $10.

It was good, not great. The noodles were a little dry to my liking and honestly, really kind of boring. No veggies or meat. Just noodles with oil and some garlic. I could make that at home. And the skewer was small, 3 small pieces of shrimp. For $10, I think it's not worth it. Moving on to the next truck.
author: Melissa T.

description: I was very excited about this place. I love garlic and after coming off a diet was down for some great noodles. I don't keep up on the food truck scene so consider this an unbiased review. Not sure what happened to the girl who claimed she got garlic powder cause mine had obviously been made with real garlic. My noodles weren't greasy and after I was done, there was no grease left in the bottom of the container. I thought the dish was delish and so did my fiancée. Why the three stars? Price. I got the yuzu shrimp with 4 small shrimp on the skewer. Also they were overlooked. Just a touch dry. The yuzu was faint and tasted more of basil. For 9 bucks I thought this was way too much for pasta, garlic and 4 small shrimp. They are making a killing. They could sell that for 6 or 7 bucks and still make a profit, but they choose to gouge their customers.
author: Callista T.

description: Back at Off the Grid Thursday with my friends from work. Spotted An the Go and I had to get the Vietnamese coffee since they make it how I like my women....Strong and Sweet. My co-worker opted for the garlic noodles with the Shrimp skewer. Looks like they are giving more garlic noodles than they did last time and the consistency of the noodles were better as well. The skewer was still tiny and ordering a whole meal from them is still expensive but I like that they've made improvements on both quality and quantity.
author: Norris T.

description:
The Noodles where perfect! The Chicken skewer was really good.
My only suggestion or request would to be have a special with less noodles and more meat.
author: john u.

description:
I've never been a big fan of Crustacean but I totally love their garlic noodles so when I saw that An The Go I had to try the famous garlic noodles again.  This time around they were tasty yet a little pricey. 

I'm not running to go back to the An family's restaurants again but when I see An The Go you can bet I will place an order of the garlic noodles.
author: Roger H.

description: Garlic noodles are delicious, even for a non garlic lover like me! The skewers are alright, but wished they had more meat. Overall, a great alternative with lines that aren't as long as Senor Sesig.
author: Emily C.

description: This truck is the bomb, and it's not just for their Garlic Noodles. This truck pumps out some of the best barbecued pork and battered prawns known to man as well. It is beautiful design wise, as the colorful exterior can be seen hundreds of feet away. The food isn't the only nice part, as the service is great as well. As for charges, well, you don't need to worry about breaking the bank.
author: Garrett P.

description:
Ran across them at SJ Moveable Eats this past weekend (7/2). The wifey and I  had the garlic noodles and a skewer each of the lemongrass chicken and the 5spice pork. 
I enjoyed the noodles more than she did, they were a bit too oily for her taste and she complained of the nasty taste in her mouth the following morning. Me, I enjoyed the oily garlicness and the chewy noodles.
Neither of the skewers were anything special. The pork needed more five spice.
author: Matt H.

description: 7.50 for some garlic noodles. I didn't think it was worth it even though it was pretty delicious. Beef skewer for 2.50. It was good but also not very worth it. Won't be coming back.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I was initially  kind of excited to find awesome food truck at the Treasure Island Flea Market, tucked in the back with all the other awesome looking food trucks. 
However, the food was not so cool. I got the garlic noodles which were really starchy, and dry basically just overdone noodles and tons of garlic. The flavor was lacking something fresh and it needed a liquid sauce or something because it left you parched but also thinking that it really, really needs Saracha. 
I also got the spring roll which was not bad. Wasn't greasy, wasnt overly fried but I felt like the meat inside smelled a bit old or off. 

Garlic noodles are such a staple and if you get them wrong it kind of kills everything else. The recipe needs to be changed pronto.
author: Tasha A.

description:
I tried An The Go at the Treasure Island Flea Market. The line was long, so i thought it must be pretty good. As I was waiting in line I heard people complaining about the wait, some people even left and decided to eat elsewhere.

I had the garlic noodles, lemongrass chicken and 5 spice pork. The chicken and pork were cooked nicely and flavorful. The garlic noodles were average. Overall, there wasn't anything spectacular about this truck.
author: Adelina W.

description:
Tried their food at Edgewood Eats last night and am completely unimpressed. $7.50 just for garlic noodles - no veg, no meat, no egg, nothing? If you want any protein with that, it's going to cost $2.50 - for three tiny pieces of beef or chicken on a stick. 

I understand that the costs of running a food truck business are not cheap, and that their garlic noodles are supposed to be 'out of this world', but I'm sorry, a food truck meal should offer better value than this.

If I can get a one-bowl meal from Eat Mo Bowl (which was next to them at yesterday's EE) for $8, I don't see why An The Go can't offer a similar level of value with their food. And, for the record, the garlic noodles were unimpressive.
author: Danielle T.

description:
I decided to stop by OtG: UN Plaza for lunch yesterday with a few friends. They got Seoul on Wheels and I was torn between garlic noodles here or egg noodles from another cart. I am a devout lover of garlic so I needed to try the esteemed garlic noodles sooner or later and sooner is yesterday. 

I saw from OtG: Upper Haight that the portion of noodles was not much for $7.50. I ordered and asked for extra garlic because that's what I want but I was ignored. The wait was roughly 5 minutes but I was wondering why mine was in a black bowl while everyone else had a long white paper box. I didn't ask for to-go but I guess I got it. It felt like the portion was even smaller than the existing box. Sigh, the taste was still simple but good even though it wasn't fulfilling enough. For $7.50, there should be a choice of meat (or veg) mixed in with the noodles.
author: Dominic T.

description: Carb city! I had the noodles & prawn special, and while everything tasted fine, the ratio of protein to noodle is ridiculous. For $9, you get an itty bitty skewer and a brick of noodles. Oodles of noodles. Noodles for days. And tasty as they are, you can only eat so many noodles before your taste buds get bored and pants get tight.
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
MEH.

Really, it's MEH. An The Go was at Genentech for lunch today. I picked up one of their 5 spice pork skewers and some others got the garlic noodles and beef skewers. 

Lack of flavour, not enough food or lacking the taste to be worth the $2.50 and it's $7.50 for a small bowl of noodles. I'd rather save money and make my own noodles from home.
author: Angela K.

description: Checked out this food truck at Off The Grid UN Plaza.  You get a box with 90% garlic noodles and a single skewer of meat. No veggies. Even if it weren't $9, it still felt like a very unhealthy bad meal.  The noodles tasted good but it's not a meal ... it's a fatty and oily side you'd order with a meal.  Unfortunately, there is nothing else you can order realistically as a meal to go with the carb-heavy, oil-drenched noodles.
author: K L.

description:
I was surprised at the quantity of noodles.  It's a lot of noodles.  I really wan't expecting so many noodles. I don't really like noodles.  Believing the portions would be different or that veggies would be mixed in, I didn't eat too many of the carb-demons and felt hungry and sad after lunch that I paid $10 for a beef skewer.

I would definitely go back to try the skewer on salad, but the noodles weren't for me.
author: Jordan F.

description:
I am shocked. After SactoMofo, I expected to come onto Yelp and add to the overly positive reviews of An The Go. Shockingly, a 3 star average? I can't believe it.

First off, let it be known that the garlic noodles were among the favorites, if not THE favorite from our crew of 8 that attended and SactoMofo. And we didn't just try 1-2 vendors. We had full meals from EIGHT places.

The noodles are simple and delicious. Couple that with the stir-fry veggies w/ tofu, and the delicious lemongrass chicken skewers and you have a winner.

I'm now planning a day in SF where I hunt down food trucks all day. An The Go will definitely be on that list.
author: Sam B.

description:
Like most food trucks, An The Go is overpriced.  Actually, it's *WAY* overpriced.  The noodles and shrimp skewer was decent, but it consisted mostly of noodles, and didn't taste that special.  It was something that I could make at home if I had generic pasta, garlic, butter and some cirgin olive oil.

The service was decent, but nothing really good or bad.

I have only tried An The Go once, and I don't see myself paying 3 times the price for something that anyone else could make.
author: Jaime J.

description:
Got garlic noodles and stir fried veggies at the Treasure Island Flea Market.  The noodles are not my style - very soft (overcooked?) and all stuck together.  Veggies were OK, but very little for $2.50 - it included 2 small slices of tofu.
I was a bit bummed, I don't get out to the food trucks too often, and "le truck" was right next door which had a great menu.  Next time...
author: Mike V.

description:
The An The Go foodtruck came to my office today and I ordered the 5-spice pork w/ Garlic Noodles ($9) and an additional shrimp skewer ($2.50).

The food itself is decent, but in my opinion, not worth the money.  The order was 90% noodles.  The shrimp skewer was 4 tiny shrimp.

Meh - I've definitely had better.
author: B G.

description:
Found this truck at the Treasure Island Flea Market.  I've never had garlic noodles before so I was a bIt hesitant in ordering thinking the garlic would be overwhelming.  Boy, was I wrong!  The garlic was just about right., not overpowering in garlic at all.

I ordered garlic noodles with both lemongrass chicken and beef skewers.  Both meats were cooked just about right - tender and juicy with good flavor.  The thing I didn't like was that there should have been more than just 3 slices of meat on each skewer.

I consider myself a food connoisseur and if you're like me, then you have to try this at least once.  Even if it's just for the garlic noodles...
author: Jayson C.

description:
I went here because it was down the road from HRD cafe (which was closed).  I was pleasantly surprised that it wasn't the rib truck (i think its called the rib whip).  I love ribs, but I wasn't in the mood for ribs.

Garlic noodles are the focus, but the ones I got seemed a bit overcooked.  I expected them to have a bit more al dente chew.  Sufficient garlic, but the price is hard to deal with for the serving size and coming from a truck.  If they were piping hot at the restaurant, then the price is right.

I ordered the shrimp and pork skewers.  They were properly done and well seasoned, but nothing stood out about them.

In terms of arrangement, it would be nice to have some green with the noodles and skewers.  The only option was a whole salad, which would be too much food and $.

Service is friendly and the line processed quickly.

Im leaving 2 stars off because I expect it to get better either in value or in uniqueness.
author: H C.

description:
The garlic noodles were just ok.  My 2 year old liked them because they were not too spicy.  I wish they sold their crab.  Unless they have crab I probably would not eat here again.

Ice Coffee was yummy.
author: MarinMama w.

description:
I have to agree with other Yelpers here ... while the garlic noodles ($7.50) are plentiful and okay tasting (if you really like garlic), I don't think most people want a meal of straight starch/carbs (there is nothing on the noodles except the garlic 'sauce').  I tried to remedy this with the chicken skewer, but the portion was pretty skimpy and the taste just average.  The two a la carte items did not merit the total $10 price tag.  (The photos of other Yelpers tell the story pretty well.)  An The Go's menu needs to be revamped.

I've been trying quite a few food trucks lately, thanks to Truck Stop SF's set up on Mission St. in the FiDi.  This truck was not one of the better experiences.
author: Jimmy G.

description: Garlic Noodles with a skewer of lemongrass grilled shrimp for nine dollars. You get a TON of noodles  and they are not shy with the garlic... But thats what they are called, its not chow mein or ramen people... Had it twice and enjoyed it both times.
author: Kelly H.

description:
I am a big fan of Thanh Long and maybe my mistake was thinking the food truck version would be just as good.

$7.50 for a good size portion of garlic noodles and $2.50 for skewers.  The garlic noodles were ok, maybe because it was steamed in my box since I did not eat it straight from the bowl like the restaurant.

The lemongrass chicken skewer was ok.  At $2.50 a skewer, that's $0.50 a bite.  Pretty steep.

I'm prob like many other people, just wanting to hop on the food truck band wagon and now that I've given it a try, I don't think I will again.  

The food trucks, not just this one, are expensive.  Prob becaue the cost of gas is built into the pricing! Ouch!!
author: Will I A m.

description:
Okay, I don't understand what everyone is whining about, the skewer was 6" long and so stuffed with meat you couldn't see or hold the stick.  On top of a very generous pile of garlic noodles.  Good comfort food.

I also had the crab puffs.  Really good, packed with real crab.  Not those big empty wrappers with a tiny dot of cream cheese you get in a Chinese restaurant.  I recommend them, but too much food with all those noodles.
author: Alan L.

description:
Saw them at Off The Grid. I was still hungry after splitting 3 tacos from Kung Fu Tacos with my girlfriend, so I went here to get some Garlic Noodles.

The Garlic Noodles were bolded on the top of their menu. Had to be their specialty so I ordered it. Its cost $7.50 for the noodles by itself and they give you a small bowl full of it. Or you can add a Chicken Skewer or another one of their other Skewers for $2.50 more. I didnt want to pay $10 so I just got the noodle, and thats what they are known for. 

The noodles were good. Garlic taste was heavy but also very oily at the bottom of the bowl. Not sure how they made them (and they guy working there wouldnt tell anyone how they made them. The guy in front of me asked how they were made and the guy behind the counter said it was a secret LOL Pretty funny conversation if you ask me!) anyways but it was oily at the bottom, but other than that it was great!

Again its pricey though, Just like all the other food trucks in SF. I liked the food but it was pricey in my opinion.
author: Daniel S.

description: I love garlic noodles, but when you order a combination plate with skewer, you'd think there's more to it.  NOPE! For $9, you get 1 pork skewer and tons of garlic noodles....and a short piece of squiggly black hair. Yum.  The people working there are genuinely nice.
author: Lisa W.

description: I'm a huge fan of Thanh Long & Crustacean, but $9 for their combo of soggy garlic noodles & 1 skewer of meat seemed unproportioned & over priced.  It should be half the amount of noodles & 2 skewers.
author: Stacey L.

description: The garlic noodles portion is big enough to share. Get a second skewer just in case.
author: Lauralai C.

description: So good. So MUCH GARLIC. Amazing. Especially for a food truck reminds me of  Thanh Long and Crustacean. I love Thanh Long and Crustacean. I was excited to see this truck and it met my approval.
author: Ashley G.

description: I love an the go, finding out where they will be is easy as they post their weekly schedule on facebook on Mondays. The pile of noodles lasts me 2 meals! I am definitely addicted to these noodles, and $9 is a fair price in my opinion.  You cant even get a deli sandwich for $9 that is as filling. If you go earlier the meat is always juicier (it makes sense if they cook it and it sits there it will start to dry out) as with any food truck or even resteraunt buffet. If you get veggies rather than a meat skewer the portiin is even bigger. I love an the go!
author: Monica K.

description:
The Good: Cool staff, good garlic noodles.

The Bad: Stir fry veggies majorly uninspired.

I was excited to try An The Go ever since Little Green Cyclo got me hooked on the garlic noodles. I wasn't craving meat, for some reason, and decided just to go with the veggie stir fry and garlic noodles. The noodles were very good, not great, but very good. The veggies, on the other hand, were not. I live in a mostly asian neighborhood and live over a Vietnamese restaurant (that servers inferior garlic noodles, btw). In addition, I spent a month in Vietnam last year and ate just about everything I could get my hands on. What An The Go served were unseasoned, steamed vegetables (broccoli, carrot, cauliflower) with flavorless tofu. I had to add salt to enjoy them. They were decently cooked, but there was no trace of Vietnamese flavors or influence. It was more like the side of veggies you would get at an American steak house. Even if I wasn't looking for Asian/Vietnamese and only wanted a vegetarian dish, this would be disappointing.

I will go back. I want try their meat and give them another shot. The staff was super cool and their service was efficient, but that veggie dish needs a major overhaul.
author: R. S.

description: While I am definitely a fan of noodles, and my love of garlic borders on the pathological, I was left wanting after my lunch visit to An the Go. The noodles had good garlic flavor but were a little soggy, as if they may have been in a warming tray for a few hours, and while the portion was humungous it was not in a good way.  I got 4 tiny shrimp and 3 pounds of noodles of $9. I would gladly have taken less noodle for a little more skewer. Over all I was unimpressed.
author: Matthew L.

description: Garlic noodles were good... tasted like garlic bread on noodles. 1 order of garlic noodles is enough to feed me twice! For the price of $7.50, it's not bad for the portion given...however, it really is just garlic noodles! Though the noodles are good, I don't understand why I have to purchase the meat separately...on a skewer... And there was barely any meat compared to the amount of noodles... Overall, I am disappointed!
author: Pansy L.

description:
I've been looking forward to having garlic noodles from An The Go ever since I heard the fine folks from Thanh Long were coming out with a truck to serve the masses.  Since I haven't been to the restaurant in a while, the thought of their delicious garlic noodles for a meal has been tempting my pallet for the better part of two days.  I arrived at OtG-McCoppin a bit before 2pm and there was no wait.  The entire box was ready in less than 5 minutes. 

The garlic noodles have always been great at the restaurant and was hoping for the same from the truck.  I thought the noodle portion was a decent size and I wasn't disappointed.  Almost as great as the noodles in the restaurant.. I say almost because eating out of a brown box just isn't quite the same.  LOL!  The noodles by itself is $7.50.  For additional $2.50 each, you can get a pork, chicken, or beef skewer.  I went with the chicken.   The chicken skewer was only OK, IMHO.   It was not as flavorful as I had expected.  

I'd give you guys five stars if you could also bring your roasted crab on the truck too!  C'mon! =)
author: A. H.

description: So what's the hype on the garlic noodles all about?... This truck did not live up to the talk at all...   $9 bucks for garlic noodles and a small piece of meat?... yes they give you ALOT but still.. it's noodles and garlic.  not exactly that hard to make.  I personally though the taste was just OK too.  left a stench in my mouth for  quite a few hours .
author: Margie C.

description: I can get the garlic noodles and eat them at home with my own crab! Wa ha ha ha! I feel like Brain having finally taken over the world (at least the garlic noodle part of the world, which is all that matters.)
author: Vena V.

description: The Vietnamese fried springs rolls were tasty BUT definitely overpriced at $6 for two measly rolls.  I could have gone to a regular restaurant and had them at about $4.00.  Food trucks are turning out to be a trendy fad that is getting a bit old nowadays, may as well just go to the old brick and mortar restaurant like we used to do.
author: Irene C.

description:
Off the Grid is back on...and An The go should "go bye bye"....after making the circle browsing my choices....this is my Friday night dinner....an important decision that can set the note for the weekend.  I saw someone with veggies, noodles and a lemongrass chicken skewer...donso!  However, I should have looked a bit closer and perhaps interviewed the diner before making my decision.  

I was so disappointed by my selection....I think my 6 year old niece could have duplicated the noodles....and the amount of veggies and chicken they give you could feed a mouse.  Very disappointed by my Friday evening selection.....on a positive note, I just poured myself another glass of wine:)
author: Kaley T.

description: Yes, we all love the not-so-Viet garlic noodles that accompany delicious Dungeness crab at Thanh Long, PPQ, and the like. Do I want a big pile of $7.50 noodles with a $2.50 skimpy skewer as a meal? NO.
author: Mimi L.

description: HUGE portion of yummy garlic noodles and small portion of meat. Basically, if you want to get the combo, order one combo for two people and add stuff - otherwise, you're going to find yourself eating the skewer within seconds and then swimming in noodles the rest of the meal. Don't get me wrong, your noodles are the best garlic noodles ever, but I need a little more meat/veggies and a little less noodle - CAPICHE?
author: Noneya B.

description: An the Go was at OTG Pleasanton today serving up $9 combos of garlic noodles plus one skewer. I ordered the beef lemongrass skewer and added an extra chicken lemongrass skewer for $2.50. I liked the beef and the chicken, but thought the noodles were dry. I don't think the noodles are made to order which is why they are dry. I personally wouldn't mind waiting a few extra minutes to have the noodles made fresh especially when paying $9. Since this truck is a mobile extension of Crustacean, sales tax is added to all orders.
author: D B.

description: I don't get why food trucks are so expensive! At least the garlic noodles from An The Go was *kiiiiiiiiiiiinda* worth it (slightly pushing it) at $9 for a box full of delicious garlic noodles and 4 pieces of meat (beef). $7.50 for garlic noodle and $2.50 for the beef skewer if you buy it separately. Of course the noodle wasn't as good as the ones at Crustacean (one of my fave restaurants in the city) or Thanh Long.
author: Natalia H.

description: Not a satisfying meal at all. Agree with other reviews - too much noodles, too little meat. Not worth it at all for $9 out of a truck... Plus, the noodles were greasy, and with absolutely no vegetables at all.
author: Rishabh K.

description:
I am a huge fan of An The Go.
Its my favorite food truck by far.
The garlic noodles and Shrimp are amazing.
When trying to be healthy and not overload on cabs, I opt for the stir fry veg with shrimp skewers.
Delicious.
I have also eaten at Thang Long-Excellent
author: Julie P.

description:
3.5 stars. The garlic noodles are not bad at all, but the Combination is overpriced at $9 - should be more like $6, or even $5.

The amount of noodles is too large, but the skewer of meat is only modest in size. Your best best is to find a date, buy one Combination ($9) with two extra skewers ($5) and you have a good-sized meal for two for $14+tip.

Super garlic breath will make your first kiss all the more memorable.
author: Michael J.

description: The garlic noodles are... not that impressive. Got them with the stir fry veggies, which were extremely remarkable.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Your food is really good, but 1 skewer and a gang load of noodles isn't really a "deal" for $10. Throw another skewer in there!
author: Jim O.

description:
they are pushing the limit, as in, how high can you charge to turn a quick profit off their family name?  $7.50 for purely garlic noodle and then each side skewer 2.50?  highway robbery.  so i only got the skewers alone, shrimp, 5 spice pork, lemongrass chicken.  grilled on a flat grill and pressed so that they stay juicy.  that's good.  flavor ok but not bursting (i.e. lemongrass)
the price wars are going the wrong direction for us--they are seeing what they can get away with, esp. without bringing new food concepts anymore.  this is a quick in and out business.
author: Rob C.

description: skewer was decent.  Garlic noodles were very disappointing.... They must use some sort of garlic powered in them because it was all clumped up.  I didnt even finish them.  All that for $9?
author: Christian M.

description:
I went to Off-the-Grid to try this food truck and to say the least, I was a little disappointed. 

It was $7.50 for garlic noodles and an additional $2.50 for meat or vegetables. I don't eat meat so I opted for vegetables, which I thought was expensive. They had better come with a lot of vegetables for that price!

When I got my food, it lacked the vegetables that I asked for. I was hoping for a heaping amount of vegetables, not three broccoli stems and one tofu cube. I felt like I was ripped-off. 

The noodles were good at first, then I realized the noodles were either overcooked, lacked flavor, and extremely unpleasantly chewy? Like they instantly became mush when you put it in your mouth, almost as if it melted. It was weird. It was kinda missing that slight crunch or even the al-denteness of it. The garlic sauce, however, was good.

I don't know if I would return, but the server was really nice and friendly.
author: K. E.

description: It was a sad day when my hopes and excitement for An the Go were crushed by my first dining experience with them. I am a big fan of the An family restaurants (Crustacean's, Thanh Long, etc.) and have always had great experiences at each location. You could imagine my excitement for the garlic noodles from their food truck. The skewers of meat are miniscule. I'm 5'4" at 118 pounds and I had to order an extra skewer. Even with this extra skewer, I was not satisfied. I ordered the shrimp and chicken, which were really just mediocre, if that. The garlic noodles were the biggest disappointment. The texture was mushy and the seasoning just wasn't there. Granted that there was a big portion of the noodles, but I only ate about 30% of it and that was with a lot of sriracha, which helped with the taste (or lack thereof). I'm glad to say I have tried An the Go for the first time, but sadly, it will be my last.
author: Priscilla V.

description:
I'm from Hawaii and have wanted to try the garlic noodles at Crustaceans for years.  I wanted to check out Off the Grid during this trip to the Bay Area and was delighted to find "An The Go".  The Upper Haight event fit our schedule best so we caught the N Muni from Powell and found the Food Trucks.  I headed for the An the Go truck and ordered the Garlic noodles with tofu vegetables and a Yuzu shrimp scewer.  The guy taking my order was really nice.  The food was sooooo good, if I wasn't so full I would have gone back for another scewer.  There was so much food that my husband had to finish my noodles.  

Upper Haight was a little spooky at night, I recommend going while its still lighted or going to a different event.  I will definitely either check out Crustaceans or find the food truck again on my next trip to the Bay area.
author: Laurie L.

description: Do you like garlic noodles? Do you like thanh long or crustacean?  Better yet, do you want to get good tasting garlic noodles at half the price? Then you better get your booty over to An The Go and get yourself some of their garlic noodles!! You get a lot for your money and get to choose what you want with it. I usually get mines with the tofu and veggies. Don't say i didn't tell you so..
author: Mertani G.

description:
I ordered the $9 rice plate combo with lemongrass chicken. Service was quick enough but you end up getting one skewer of chicken to a lot of rice, a few veggies, and some tofu. It feels like a ripoff since you're barely getting any meat at all.

The food itself is not bad but I can think of few food trucks that would be worse bang for your buck.
author: Rajiv P.

description:
parking is crazy and away from near the truck...lol.  well, i go to this if they're at the OTG-off the grid, haight event.

so i saw other people eating it.  i actually saw a man and his 4 kids eating the noodles for what seemed a long time.  it looked like a lot so i decided to try it out.

one thing right away.  the bbq sticks are not all cooked before hand so they are burned or extremely dried out.  they cook them partially, then fully cook them to your order.  that would make it seem GREAT!  Sadly, for the chicken...i was disappointed.  it wasn't all that fresh as i'd hoped.  in fact, it didn't make a difference to me if they had precooked it and had it ready before i ordered or if they cooked it after i ordered it.

the noodles were cooked perfectly and there was LOTS of GARLIC so it brings it back to okay,. 

the price for the noodles is 7.50.  if you have the noodles and a bbq stick.  its 9 dollars.  for the size of the bbq stick...it should be 7.50 for the bbq stick and the noodles.

so hence the 3 stars.

i had the chicken...

next time, if there is a next time, i'm going to try the beef.  5 spice pork sounds good...but if the pork isn't sliced thin, it might not compare to other places...so i guess beef is the best choice here.
author: Bing D.

description: I had An The Go at Moveable Feast today, and it was quite good.  I had yuzu shrimp skewers as well.  Some people on Yelp said they come out try and tough, and they must have read the reviews -- mine were fantastic. The garlic noodles were also great, and a rather large helping at that.
author: Charles Y.

description: Really enjoy this food truck, one of my favorites when it comes to Off the Grid! Garlic noodles are delicious, and you get a full meal with some skewers and side dish.
author: Becky C.

description: The noodles are great--but there needs to be veggies and more protein tossed in them--or the option for same.  A bit pricey for lots of noodles and 5 smallish shrimp on a skewer.
author: Gretchen J.

description: Love the garlic noodles, but just wish they could be a little more efficient since everytime I go to their truck, the line is enormous. Still, the wait is worth it since the food is so good and cheap with pretty good portions.
author: Lucas P.

description: GARLIC NOODLES SO GOOD. but uhhh dont get the meat with it. its a small amount.. like TINY amount. not worth the extra 2.50 and try to eat the noodles as fast as you can while theyre warm. they kinda get boring when cold
author: Rebecca K.

description: This is the very first time I am putting a review on Yelp... I was VERY disappointed with "An the Go". I had the garlic noodles from their truck food at civic center and it was.... disgusting. and not too say WAY Overpriced! $9 for overcooked noodles sprinkled with garlic powder??  and the veggies were far from fresh.. My friend and I couldn't even finish our dishes.. I didn't think it possible to mess up a simple dish like garlic noodles that bad... Nope, it's a No Go.
author: Baba D.

description: Amazing garlic noodles and lemongrass chicken skewer. Big portions, you do get your money's worth.
author: Fabian S.

description: Saw a guy who works at An The Go, order from Chairman Bao..me and my bf laughed...even the employee is over it hahaha!
author: John S.

description: Garlic noodles are really good! Not spicy and most of all plain, just how I like them. Didn't have any extras like pepper flakes or cilantro like other places do. I had it with a chicken skewer which was also awesome. My only complaint was I didn't finish because I found a piece of hair in it. :( hate that.
author: Kiki K.

description: Love the Garlic Noodles with Beef skewers!!!  I always have enough left over for lunch the next day!!
author: Angela N.

description: Tried this truck during a movable feast day.   The garlic noodles was okay but I have had better, not sure if my noodles were sitting around but it was a bit cold .  Price and quantity to me doesn't match up so need to fix that if I'm shelling out my hard earned money.
author: Grant L.

description: They turn out a perfected cafe su da that will keep you in Vietnamese caffeine heaven for hours on end. Strong coffee and not to sweet, just like I like 'em.
author: Lee H.

description: As good as garlic noodles from a truck can get! The consistency of the noodles and the amount of garlic are perfect. Unless you have some backwards expectation for food trucks, it's impossible to come away disappointed from An The Go. There's no doubt I'd be pushing 300lbs if this truck came by my office every workday.
author: Michael L.

description: $9 for garlic noodles with FOUR small shrimps? You eat half of the it and all that is left are garlic noodles. And it's no special garlic noodles either.
author: Bruno N.

description:
2.5 stars rounded up to 3 because the food's tasty.  But like everyone else says, it's too much noodle and too little meat, especially for the $9 price.

And there's not really much depth of flavor. Just garlic and more garlic. If the price were a little lower, I wouldn't mind sharing this with a couple other people as an appetizer/side of sorts, but as a meal by itself, I'd definitely skip it and head over to another food truck.
author: D E.

description: Saddest Lunch I've had in a long time... Had the chicken combo...  Not enough meat and no veggies with the noddles.  Keep walking.
author: Dave C.

description: $9 for a pile of noodles and a small skewer of meat.  Biggest food truck ripoff ever.
author: Aaron C.

description: I can't help but like the garlic noodles, but this place is kinda a rip.  $7.50 for just the noodles is pretty ridic.  Plain garlic noodles. Every skewer costs an additional $2.50...it adds up pretty quickly.  That being said, I had an awesome lunch by adding some cucumber kimchi from Bowl'd.  Layering garlicky goodness just...um...yum.
author: Candace C.

description: The building I work in has been having food trucks come by like everyday, and An the Go was one of them.  Having been to Crustacean before I was totally stoked! However I was pretty disappointed. The only saving grace with the vietnamese spring rolls or egg rolls, those were delicious.  The noodles were okay, and they gave only 4 baby shrimp to go along with them for a whopping $15.  I was expecting bargain basement prices by any means, but for what I got, I was not that impressed. The shrimp did have a good flavor, but the noodles were SOOOO garlicky that they gave me a tummy ache.  I wouldn't spend my money at this truck again...
author: Mariela L.

description: These noodles are amazing! Such a yummy, filling comfort food and the guys working the truck are awesome, too. Eating here is a treat. Oh, and the meat! So yummy!
author: Jessica H.

description:
lots of garlic noodles with a small skewer of meat. literally, the noodles are not mixed with any complementary ingredients typical for noodles like carrots, peas, cilantro, or whatever else. just noodles and garlic.

i thought it worked though and that it was carbaliciously delicious, but trying this today was my first time ever having garlic noodles so i have no reference. price was $9
author: Skinny L.

description: An the Go is pretty decent as far as the food itself, but as others have already written, it's the cost that gets you.  The garlic noodles are good, but not outrageous good.  You can get some pretty similar noodles at a lot of different fast foody type chinese places.  If you're getting regular chow mein from somewhere and miss that garlic taste, just throw some garlic powder in there.  The skewers are likewise good, but not knock you off your seat good.  All in all, I don't feel like I'm getting $10 worth.  If the truck happens to be right there and I've got $10 to spare, I might hit it up, but I'm certainly not going to go hunting it.  If you're at a Moveable Feast or somewhere with other food trucks, you've probably got better options.
author: Bay Area Eaters ..

description:
I think if I could I'd give An the Go 2.5 stars, the food was pretty mediocre. While visiting Off the Grid Civic Center and seeing that Chairman Bao's had a monstrous line going, I decided to line up for the truck that seemed to be the fastest/had the shortest line so that's how I ended up at An the Go that day. I had heard that they were owned by Crustacean, but based on Yelp reviews and looking at people's garlic noodles at Off the Grid I wasn't super pumped for my garlic noodles. First of all, just noodles cost $7.50 - and that is literally what you will get, just garlic and noodles, no vegetables, not even a green onion. 

If you order noodles only you get it in a pretty sturdy looking piece of plastic ware, but it's fairly small. If you add a skewer or vegetables to your noodle you get your food all in a paper box that is an upgrade in size from the plastic container. If you find that you like the food here, I'd say add skewer to your noodles for the meat, and extra noodles. 

Now for the food, the noodles were just boring. They looked sort of like spaghetti and chow mein noodles at the same time, mixed with a ton a garlic and were quite greasy. The noodles are filling, but I got sick of them really fast. The main problem with the noodles is that they lack firm texture, they almost reminded me of noodles that had been sitting in water for too long and had absorbed too much liquid. The noodles are very plump and mushy so they fill you up fast, but after awhile it ends up tasting like garlic mush, and the garlic is fairly intense. To add some variety to the texture I think they need to either add some onions, or fried garlic slices for a crunch, it was just too mushy! I also got a lemongrass beef skewer which was actually really good. The meat was juicy and tender and wasn't too salty, for $2.50 it was pretty decent. They also sell drinks here but I didn't bother since I was already shelling out $10 for bland noodles and one skewer. I couldn't finish my box of noodles for lunch so I stuck it in the fridge and came back to it after a few hours. I will admit that this improved the noodles. By chilling the noodles it became slightly firmer and the garlic flavor a little sharper, but I still wasn't in love with it.

I got my food fairly fast, so that was a plus considering how crowded Off the Grid lunch events can get and I was running short on time for my lunch break. I don't think I'd go to An the Go again, for $7.50 I expect some pretty spectacular noodles (especially if it's noodles ONLY). I might be tempted to order just a skewer in the future, but I'd stay clear of those noodles.
author: Monica W.

description: Completely disappointed in my boring noodles and overcooked, semi-burnt chicken. Horrible.
author: Danny M.

description: Boo! How do they have the galls to sell butter noodles and garlic sauce for $7.50? There's no veggies, no meat just greasy shlock smeared over some cheap, generic type noodles that were store bought. Their restaurants are also over priced and DIRTY. Please make a note of this if you drive past their Polk street location. Dirty windows, dirty carpets, the place if filthy. Nasty food, avoid this place.
author: Kato D.

description: It's a great way to get your garlic noodle fix during lunch in the city. It's not exactly the same, without a Thanh Long Roast Crab to go with it, but it helps random cravings.
author: Jonathan V.

description: Not so great.. Lacking in any interesting flavors. I got the garlic noodles, added veggies and beef and had one fried roll and it was 15 bucks.
author: miss m.

description: I really can't get enough of An the Go's garlic noodles and usually end up at this truck when it's at either UN Plaza or Civic Center. That said, it's really expensive. Yes, you're getting about 3 servings of spaghetti drenched in garlicky, buttery goodness, but at the end of the day you're getting spaghetti for  $7.50--$10 if you get something with it. And for that extra $2.50 you're getting 3 teeny, tiny shrimps. For $2.50, I would expect double that. More recently I decided to switch to stir-fried veggies, which was really good (they even threw in a couple pieces of tofu!). But the total dish would only be worth $10 if I was sitting down to a white tablecloth in a restaurant. When I go to a food truck, I want cheap with my tasty.
author: Amy B.

description: What a discovery! Each bite of the garlic noodles were pure heaven coming off of a gourmet truck. A close comparison to Crustacean & Thang Long restaurant which I love very much in San Fransisco. I found this place at the movable feast downtown San Jose.
author: Tellis H.

description: I should have seen these comments on the Yelp first before I tried the food.  I ordered the garlic noodle with the beef skewer for $10 (Wow, really?)  The noodle tasted like it was there for over 30 min and very dull....  Believe me, I'm a "garlic" and "butter" lover and I give them only 2 stars only because the skewer was just ok.
author: C MH L.

description: I hear so much about the restaurant so I figured this ought to give me a chance to try the place without actually visiting the place. The food truck was at the Treasure Island Flea market and had the longest line besides the donut stand. The noodles cost $7.50 for a relatively small bowl. You can see the size of the bowl in pictures. It was enough to fill me up. It tasted good but it wasn't all it was cracked up to be. I hear so much about how good the garlic noodles are, so I guess my expectations were higher than they should have been. But, they were alright, worth a try if you've never tried them before. I kinda want to go to Crustacean to try the noodles there now though.
author: Annie W.

description:
Friendly service and convenient but not even close compared to the restaurant.  

IMO a big reason it just doesn't stand out is because the truck does not offer Crab as a meat choice.  I think the crab is the great complement that brings out the flavor in the garlic noodles.

I understand offering crab would be difficult but why not offer crab meat instead of full on crab?
author: Eric L.

description: I had the pleasure of trying their garlic noodle and kabobs at the Moveable Eats in SJ.  Looved it!  I actually like the noodle more than the kabobs, however, they accompany each other fairly well.  It is definitely a hit!  All the kabobs were fairly good, I liked the chicken especially more though.  I wish they come to SJ more often.
author: Amie L.

description: I've been wanting to try this food truck since I love the Thanh Long noodles.  It is definitely way overpriced for a stick of meat and some ramen noodles cooked in butter and garlic.  Their service is very poor and the cashier is not very helpful and is also overpaid for what she does.  To sum it up, poor service and overpriced food.
author: Carmen M.

description: Located across from City Hall on the park side along with other food trucks during lunch weekdays. The garlic noodles had a good garlicky aroma and portion was decent. I added the lemongrass chicken to the order for 10 bucks, fast service and very friendly service. Yes, I agree with other reviews that it lack any color and adding some  veggies would have gotten a more higher ratings. Even a little green onion, seaweed flakes, sesame seeds, etc. would have made it a big difference!
author: Wolfy W.

description: I love garlic noodles and An the Go had it going with the flavor except the noodles is a bit soggy.  i think they overcook it, otherwise it would be awesome.  I had their beef on the stick also, but it was a little underdone.  Flavor of the beef is ok.  That's it for my two cents.
author: Armi S.

description: Got a chance to stop by during SJ eats and the lemongrass chicken skewers were tasty! I'm a big fan of lemongrass and the flavors were definitely there.  Loved it even more for $2.50 each.
author: Cindy T.

description: The noodles were not that great. The garlic stuff was garlic powder and the noodles were a bit too soft. I've made better tasting noodles at home. The lemon grass chicken skewer wasn't that great either. I've made better food at home. Anyway, this was not worth my money. Greatest disappointment so far at Off the Grid.
author: Breniel L.

description: Went to OTG: UN Plaza and was pretty surprised to see a food truck serving my favorite garlic noodles from Thanh Long so I had to line up. I got the garlic noodles for $7.50 and the beef skewer for an additional $2.50. Considering I just spent $10 bucks at a food truck, I expected my meal to be a little more satisfying-- but it wasn't. I got a disproportionately big serving of noodles coupled with a very lame looking skewer of beef. $7.50 should be able to cover an entire meal at a food truck and not just a portion of it. I'll be sticking to restaurant version of Thanh Long in the future where at least I feel like I'm paying for overpriced garlic noodles because the restaurant has costs and upkeep.
author: Angelo T.

description: Finally caught up with An The Go at Off The Grid Civic Center this afternoon.  I'm a fan of the garlic noodles at Crustacean!  I ordered the Garlic Noodles $7.50 and a Yuzu Shrimp Skewer for $2.50.  The noodles were good, but didn't taste as flavorful as the ones at the restaurant.  The shrimp were flavorful, tender and just slightly crispy on the outside... perfect!... but there were only three.  Overall I enjoyed my meal but I was underwhelmed with the value.  For $10.00 I could have found a bit better food with table service at a sit down.  The portion of the noodles were generous, almost too much not to share.  I would have felt better getting 1/2 the noodles for 1/2 the price.
author: Seth G.

description: Overpriced. $9 for 3 oz of sub-par chicken and a box of garlic spaghetti is ludicrous. It tastes OK, but I wouldn't pay more than $5 for this at the very most.
author: M J.

description:
$10 for noodles and a skewer. That's all there was - noodles and a skewer. No scallions, no spices, nothing else. Noodles were mushy and overcooked, not sauteed in any recognizable way. Meat was extraordinarily average. I'm not sure if should complain about the small portion size, or be relieved. 

These guys are just scamming the food truck wave, don't let them win!
author: Wangston P.

description: I headed out to Bishop Ranch 3, on a quest for cupcakes from That's Sweet Dessert Truck (5 stars). But as I was driving on Bollinger, I saw my cupcake truck driving away in the opposite direction =/ boooo. I proceeded to Bishop Ranch, in hopes they'd return, but the didn't. Since I made the trek all the way I decided to pick up lunch from An The Go. I wasn't hungry (for anything but cupcakes) but I had always wanted to try An's famous noodles. I've actually made these noodles a few times, for my family. I got a knock-off recipe off the internet. I've eaten at Crustaceans before, a long, long time ago and it was fabulous. So I was excited to try their famous noodles. When I got my lunch special order ($9 for noodles and a lemon grass beef skewer), the box was very hefty feeling. It came with a minimal portion of beef and a lot of noodles. The lemon grass beef was very tasty. The noodles were a notch above my own. The leftover noodles was enough to eat for dinner. I was sufficiently satisfied with the taste and quality of my food. $9 is reasonable, compared to the prices they charge at their restaurant. Now I know how to tweak my own garlic noodles.
author: Tracy S.

description:
An The Go is like the hipper younger child-project derived from the owners of the restaurants Crustacean and Thanh Long. The shiny red food truck itself proudly informs you of their affiliation and emphasizes to you their go-to thing is definitely the garlic noodle. Additionally, a whiff of the garlic aroma (or "stench" if you a vampire) can be smelled from a few trucks down. 

The menu is quite simple - garlic noodles for $7.50, and the choice of either (a) lemongrass beef skewer, (b) lemongrass chicken skewer, (c) 5-spice pork skewer, (d) stir-fry tofu and veggies, or some other choices for an additional $2.50. Today there was also a choice of Coconut Prawns or Mix Green Salad with Miso as side dishes. By no means is the menu extensive, I mean... it is a food truck. I stuck with garlic noodles + lemongrass beef. 

One cool thing I just noticed is that these food trucks take credit card! So for you cash-strapped folks good news, Visa or Mastercard can spot you for your lunch. Now on to the food... I was shocked at the portions... and not in a good way. I opened by box and what stared back at me was such small portions. It looked as if someone had eaten half my lunch and doggy-bagged the rest for me. "Mr. An, I did not order a half-order of the food. Did someone in the truck get hungry and ate the other half of my portion?"  I had thought for $2.50 there would at least be 2 skewers of lemongrass beef.

Lemongrass beef was cold and really not all that flavorful. To me, it could have been beef jerky for all I knew. The garlic noodle was crisp on the edges and tasted of buttery and garlicy goodness. But for a cheaper price, I can sit at a restaurant and get comparable garlic noodle from Red Crawfish or Mangosteen. I did not really see the hoo-ha of the garlic noodles. They were good... but not "ZOMG! It's garlic noodles from the owners of Crustacean / Thanh Long!"-good. Might considering making a return if they (1) lower the price or (2) increase the damn portions.
author: Kevin L.

description: Went back here on Wednesday and the chicken on the garlic noodles was much grosser then I had ever seen it. Really fatty and seemed almost undercooked. I may go back but I will not get their chicken again.
author: Jenny A.

description: Bomb ass noodles & coffee! Finally hit the front of the line, and can't wait for next months moveable feast!
author: Amy B.

description: The garlic noodles are tasy, but as others have said, $9 for the combo plate that consisted of a pile of noodles and a little skewer is a rip.  I've had expensive food truck portions, but this feels lazy and excessive.
author: Daniel C.

description:
An the Go - don't waste your time or your money!  I couldn't even eat the $7.50 container of nothing but overcooked sprinkled with Garlic Salt Noodles if that's what you want to call them.  I didn't want to give any stars but this site forced me to give one star. UGH!  Also if you want anything to go with those nasty noodles pull out your pocketbook, ouch and be sucker punched again.  I got the lemongrass beef, it was 3 quarter size pieces of meat on a skewer.  Almost as bad as the noodles but one step up for presentation.

Save yourself, try the other trucks, this one is a rip off from the word Go.

Going to barf up my noodles now!
author: Debbie b.

description:
I went to the recent Sj Eats just for An The Go.  I love the garlic noodles at Crustacean and Thanh Long and loved them here as well.  If you love garlic, you'll love the garlic noodles.  

I tried a variety of the kabobs (beef, chicken and pork) and all were delicious and tender.  I found the pork to be the standout from the three that I ordered.  I was surprised with the beef being pretty tender since a lot of places will overcook beef but not here.  

At the end, I am very pleased with An The Go and the fact that I didn't have to drive to San Francisco to get the food was awesome.
author: Brennan F.

description:
first off, i am a total FAN of Thanh Long, so when i heard that an the go was going to be at otg at haight and stanyan, i had to make sure that i tried their foods.

ordered the garlic noodles, duhh...beef skewer and chicken skewer...

I LOVE NOODLES, and their noodles are good, but sticky. I could definitely taste the garlic...sooo yummmm

chicken skewer was blehh..it was COLD! what  a killa!

beef skwer tho was warm and tasted soooo yummmy..its a must if ya see this food truck..
author: Cali L.

description:
The noddles were soggy and disgusting.
I had to throw the noodles away.
author: Oboro M.

description:
I'm very disappointed with An the Go.  Tried them for the first time at OTG at Valencia and McCopin.  Presentation was terrible.  White noodles in a white box with a beige pork skewer.  People eat with their eyes too, not just their palate. There should have been a salad with it to add some color. It was overpriced for the two.  $10 was way too much for the amount you got.
The other two trucks had combos that were cheaper and gave a lot more.
As for taste, my friend makes a better garlic noodle.  An the Go's noodles were doughy and mushy.  I will say the skewer was good with the 5 spice.
The best was the guy inside wno was very cute.  They should make the food look "cute" too.
author: lori l.

description:
walking up to this truck, i was excited to try what smelled like amazing food....

$9 for a large container of what seemed like spaghetti tossed with garlic powder and a single small skewer of spiced pork is ridiculous. There were a lot of noodles, but so much that I couldn't even finish it. Would have rather had an additional skewer of meat and less noodles. The spiced pork was delicious, but just not enough.

$5 for two crispy rolls which were oily and def not worth $5

$14 for a meal that completely disappointed..what a waste.
author: Vijay K.

description: Pretty much as everyone else here states... for $9 you get tons of noodles and a tiny portion of meat on a skewer. The garlic noodles are delicious, but the meal is probably realistically/fairly worth (in my food truck passion opinion) $5 tops for the noodles and $1.50 for the anemic skewer. An The Go is resting on the laurels of its parent restaurant efforts. I appreciate the fact that they started a truck to bring their flavors to other cities, but it's over priced and underwhelming in value.
author: Willow O.

description: I've been to An the Go at the SF Truckstop on Mondays on first and Mission, and most recently at the Treasure Island flea market this last weekend.  I do feel that the garlic noodles at the restaurant are better than at the truck.  Having said that though, the truck offers the convenience of bringing the noodles to you even though they are not as good as the restaurant's.  For $9 you get a ton of noodles and also a topping such as vegetables, or pork, or shrimp or chicken.  I recommend sharing this dish or splitting it into two meals to eat on different days or else you will suffer from carb and calorie overload!  I will definitely eat here again when the garlic noodle craving hits!  I wish they had half size portions for half the price, but then the economics of that pricepoint may not work out for them as a business, and having to deal with different sizes could affect their order fulfillment times.
author: Bebe W.

description: mmmmm...hair stuck in the deep fried wrapper of the egg roll!! I was still hungry so chucked the first and tried to eat the second one, and that had a piece of hair stuck in the wrapper too!
author: Elena R.

description: I am a huge fan of these garlic noodles. I've tried them at Off the Grid and Moveable feast. The noodles are tasty and flavorful without being greasy.  It is a great value too because they give a huge portion. Staff is friendly and prompt.
author: Valerie T.

description: Garlic noodles sounded so good! Alas, with the number of delicious food options around here $9 for garlicky noodles and a few steamed veggies is just too much.
author: Kiely H.

description: The garlic noodles are good but it's nothing that I would go out of my way to buy again. I had the lemon grass chicken with my noodles which was good, but for $9.00 I was expecting at lest 2 skewers. No I am not a cheapo like some other yelper said. For 9 dollars in this economy I do expect it to be worth my money. Eh, you tube, grab a cook book,  and make the noodles yourself.
author: Sdmomma R.

description: wow! i never thought the day would come where i could just walk down a street and run in to garlic noodles of Thang Long/Crustacean fame. i've only had those noodles once in my life and i remember them being amazing. and after tasting them again yesterday, they remain amazing. and on the truck it's $7.50. at the restaurant, a side is $9.50 for basically the same portion. yes please!
author: Regina C.

description: lunch plate: chicken & pork and rice...yummm....we also have side of garlic noodle...delicious
author: Pikachu P.

description: the garlic noodles is just garlic on noodles (the name is also what it is).  and yet the line is like 20 minutes long.  i feel like i'm in crazy town.  it's just garlic and noodles together. that's it.  nothing else.  it's just like two things pushed around together in a pan.  two things that both cost less than 50 cents. then they are served together. that's it.  i just. . .don't follow.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Hubby and I do a lot of food trucks, and we agreed that the pork and chicken skewers were probably the tastiest meats we have had in recent memory.  Shrimp and beef were good, not great.  We didn't order the noodles (which is probably good, given how angry so many yelpers seem to be about that). But if you like good meat, try the pork and chicken, and then come back and thank me later.
author: H A.

description: The garlic noodles were yummy and very garlicky ... couldn't even finish 1/2 the order and had to share with a friend.  The chicken skewer was just ok.  Would order the noodles again the next time the truck's near work.
author: Betty H.

description: i'm a big fan of thanh long so when i saw the "an the go" food truck at the UN plaza today, i had to get their garlic noodles.  the line was long but luckily it was a nice day today so i didn't mind waiting.  after 10 min, i finally ordered and added the 5 spice pork skewer to go with it. i noticed that the portion of noodles was more than if you ordered the noodles alone. so for $10 it's a pretty good deal. i couldn't wait to eat.  i was mildly disappointed because, although the noodles were garlicy with flavor, they were cold and not as tasty as they usually are when you order them from the restaurant.  the pork skewer wasn't bad though nothing spectacular.  after a quick nuke in the microwave, the noodles tasted better.
author: Vic S.

description: i'm basing my review on their garlic noodles. total bang for your buck! an family restaurants have the best garlic noodles hands down. and the fact that i can go right down the street during lunch in the financial dist. makes it even better.
author: sf b.

description: Noodles were good, but they need to put more than three shrimp in with the noodles. Seriously. It's just an instant disappointment when you open the box and you see three very lonely looking shrimp sitting on top of a pile of noodles. I'll skip this one next time.
author: Troy H.

description: Seriously delicious. The garlic noodles are killer. I got it with veggie stir fry veggies crispy and tofu was on point. So yummy!
author: Tia C.

description: Went to San Mateo Moveable Feast and saw a long line for a truck.  Looked a little closer and saw it was Garlic Noodles from Crustacean Restaurant.   Immediately got to the end of the line and waited.  Awesome Noodles!!!   Had a beef skewer that was juicy and flavorful.   Tried other garlic noodles and there is no comparison.   Guy at the window was nice and helpful..
author: Jeffrey H.

description: I had to create a Yelp account just to review this truck. Horrible. Ten dollars for noodles that probably cost 50 cents and a skewer of chicken that looked great and charbroiled until you bite into it and notice it's basically raw. I hope I spit it all out and don't get food poisoning. Never again.
author: Sindy S.

description: Came out to $10 for a plate of mushy noodles and a tiny piece of meat. I would have been better off with a bag of beef jerky and a packet of ramen noodles sprinkled with garlic salt. This place would maybe get 4 stars if the noodles didn't have the texture of mash potatoes, it didn't cost so damn much, and had at least some vegetables or sauce (very bland boring flavor and not very interesting to look at). It doesn't get 1 star cause at least the portion of the noodles was fair (although the $2.50 extra for one lousy piece of meat is ridiculous) and it didn't taste completely horrible. Also I don't understand why the line was so long. In any other circumstance, I would have never waited 45 minutes just for some stupid overpriced noodles but I had time to kill  cause I was a vendor at a convention right by the food truck and the convention was pretty much a ghost town I was falling asleep at if I sat in there the whole time..
author: Mike Hawk U.
